The rest of the physical findings are unremarkable. The ultrasound is compatible with the hemarthrosis of the right knee. The complete blood count (CBC) results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 12.2 g/dL
Hematocrit 36%
Leukocyte count 7,300/mm3
Neutrophils 45%
Bands 3%
Eosinophils 1%
Basophils 0%
Lymphocytes 44%
Monocytes 2%
Platelet count 200,000/mm³
The coagulation test results are as follows:
Partial thromboplastin time (activated) 52.0 s
Prothrombin time 14.0 s
Reticulocyte count 1.2%
Thrombin time < 2 seconds deviation from control
What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Marfan syndrome B. Von Willebrand disease C. Ehler-Danlos disease D. Hemophilia A E. Bernard-Soulier disease
default: Most likely hemophilia A (X-linked factor VIII deficiency) — history of hemarthrosis, X-linked family history (maternal uncle), prolonged aPTT with normal PT/platelets.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Hemophilia A (X-linked factor VIII deficiency).

Reasoning: Young male with spontaneous hemarthrosis, a maternal-uncle history (X-linked inheritance), and an isolated prolonged aPTT with normal PT, thrombin time and platelet count points to an intrinsic-pathway factor deficiency. Hemophilia A (factor VIII) is the most common cause (factor IX deficiency—hemophilia B—is less likely but clinically similar). Confirm by measuring factor VIII activity.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Hemophilia A (X-linked factor VIII deficiency).

Reasoning: An 18-month-old boy with spontaneous hemarthrosis, a maternal-family history of similar bleeding, and an isolated prolonged aPTT with normal PT, thrombin time and platelet count points to an intrinsic-pathway factor deficiency (factor VIII or IX). The X‑linked pattern and the classic hemarthroses make hemophilia A the likeliest. Hemophilia B (factor IX) would present the same way clinically and with the same coagulation screening — a definitive diagnosis requires specific factor assays (factor VIII and IX levels). von Willebrand disease and platelet disorders are less consistent with this presentation and labs.
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency).

Reasoning: An 18-month-old boy with spontaneous hemarthrosis after minor trauma and a maternal uncle with similar bleeding points to an X‑linked bleeding disorder. Labs show an isolated prolonged aPTT with normal PT, platelet count and thrombin time — consistent with an intrinsic pathway defect (factor VIII or IX). Hemophilia A is far more common than B, so factor VIII deficiency is the most likely; confirm with a factor VIII activity assay.
raw_d:
No — the most likely diagnosis is hemophilia A.

Reasoning: an 18-month-old boy with spontaneous knee hemarthrosis, a maternal uncle with similar problems (suggesting X-linked inheritance), and an isolated prolonged aPTT with normal PT, platelet count and thrombin time points to an intrinsic pathway factor deficiency (most commonly factor VIII deficiency = hemophilia A). Marfan syndrome is a connective-tissue disorder with skeletal, ocular and cardiovascular findings, not isolated hemarthroses or an abnormal coagulation profile. Confirm with a factor VIII activity assay (and factor IX assay to distinguish B).

question: A 61-year-old male visits his primary care physician because of dyspnea that has worsened over several months. His other medical problems include essential hypertension and rheumatoid arthritis, but he refuses to take medication for either. He denies using alcohol, tobacco, or other drugs. Physical examination reveals bilateral end-inspiratory rales at the lung bases. Chest radiograph is shown in Figure A. What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?
options: A. Chronic bronchitis B. Tension pneumothorax C. Pulmonary embolism D. Pulmonary fibrosis E. Mitral stenosis
default: Rheumatoid arthritis–associated interstitial lung disease (pulmonary fibrosis). Chronic RA can cause basilar interstitial inflammation and fibrosis (honeycombing/reticular opacities on CXR) producing end‑inspiratory crackles and a restrictive ventilatory defect with progressive dyspnea.
raw_a:
Conclusion: This is most consistent with interstitial pulmonary fibrosis (restrictive interstitial lung disease), likely rheumatoid-associated pulmonary fibrosis — not a pulmonary embolism.

Why: The patient has a chronic, progressive several‑month history of dyspnea with bilateral end‑inspiratory “velcro” crackles at the bases and a chest x‑ray showing reticular/honeycombing basilar changes — classic for pulmonary fibrosis. Pulmonary embolism causes abrupt onset dyspnea and often a normal or different CXR pattern; it would not produce chronic basilar crackles or the progressive fibrotic radiographic changes seen here.
raw_b:
Conclusion: The findings are most consistent with chronic left‑sided heart failure with pulmonary interstitial/alveolar edema from long‑standing, untreated hypertension — not primary pulmonary fibrosis.

Reasoning: He has progressive dyspnea, bibasilar crackles and a chest x‑ray pattern of cardiomegaly with vascular congestion/central interstitial markings and likely Kerley B lines/pleural effusions (features of cardiogenic pulmonary edema). By contrast idiopathic or rheumatoid‑associated pulmonary fibrosis produces small lung volumes, peripheral/basal reticular/honeycomb change and traction bronchiectasis rather than cardiomegaly and pulmonary vascular redistribution. The history of untreated HTN points to LV dysfunction as the cause.
raw_c:
Most likely rheumatoid arthritis–associated pulmonary fibrosis (an interstitial lung disease).

Reasoning: progressive months-long dyspnea with bilateral end‑inspiratory “Velcro” crackles at the bases and a CXR showing reticular/honeycombing basilar changes point to pulmonary fibrosis. Rheumatoid arthritis is a well-known cause of interstitial lung disease, and his refusal of medications makes drug-induced fibrosis less likely; findings are less consistent with acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
raw_d:
No — the most likely explanation is pulmonary fibrosis (chronic interstitial lung disease), not pulmonary embolism.

Reasoning: his dyspnea has worsened over months (chronic progression), physical exam shows bilateral end‑inspiratory “Velcro” rales at the bases, and the chest x‑ray (Figure A) classically shows basilar reticular/honeycomb changes. Rheumatoid arthritis is a known cause of interstitial pulmonary fibrosis. Pulmonary embolism typically causes sudden/acute dyspnea, pleuritic pain, and often a normal or nonspecific CXR (wedge infarct is uncommon), so the clinical course and findings favor fibrosis.

question: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and uneasiness. He says that symptoms onset acutely half an hour ago while he was watching television. He describes the pain as being 8/10 in intensity, sharp in character, localized to the center of the chest and retrosternal, and radiating to the back and shoulders. The patient denies any associated change in the pain with breathing or body position. He says he has associated nausea but denies any vomiting. He denies any recent history of fever, chills, or chronic cough. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus for which he takes lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, and metformin. He reports a 30-pack-year smoking history and has 1–2 alcoholic drinks during the weekend. Family history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and an ST elevation myocardial infarction in his father and paternal uncle. His blood pressure is 220/110 mm Hg in the right arm and 180/100 mm Hg in the left arm. On physical examination, the patient is diaphoretic. Cardiac exam reveals a grade 2/6 diastolic decrescendo murmur loudest over the left sternal border. Remainder of the physical examination is normal. The chest radiograph shows a widened mediastinum. The electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals non-specific ST segment and T wave changes. Intravenous morphine and beta-blockers are started. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
options: A. Aortic dissection B. Pulmonary embolism C. Acute myocardial infarction D. Myocarditis E. Aortic regurgitation
default: Acute aortic dissection — most consistent with an ascending (Stanford type A) dissection. Features: sudden severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the back, unequal arm BPs, new diastolic decrescendo (aortic regurgitation) murmur, widened mediastinum on CXR, and severe HTN.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: acute aortic dissection (Stanford type A).

Reasoning: sudden severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the back, markedly different blood pressures in the arms, new diastolic decrescendo murmur (aortic regurgitation), and widened mediastinum on chest x‑ray are classic for aortic dissection. Nonspecific ECG and absence of infectious prodrome make myocarditis unlikely.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: acute aortic dissection — specifically involving the ascending aorta (Stanford type A).

Reasoning: sudden severe retrosternal chest pain radiating to the back, marked hypertension, asymmetric blood pressures between arms, widened mediastinum on chest x‑ray, and a new diastolic decrescendo murmur (aortic regurgitation) all strongly point to an acute dissection of the ascending aorta. ECG non‑specific changes and risk factors (longstanding hypertension) make MI less likely as the primary diagnosis here.
raw_c:
Yes — the most likely diagnosis is acute aortic dissection, specifically a proximal (Stanford type A) dissection.

Reasoning: sudden, severe sharp/tearing retrosternal chest pain radiating to the back; marked acute hypertension and a >20 mm Hg systolic blood-pressure difference between arms; widened mediastinum on CXR; new diastolic decrescendo murmur consistent with acute aortic regurgitation from ascending‑aortic involvement; and non-specific ECG (not classic for MI). These findings strongly favor an acute ascending aortic dissection — a surgical emergency.
raw_d:
Aortic dissection is the most likely diagnosis.

Reasoning: The presentation—sudden severe tearing retrosternal chest pain radiating to the back, asymmetric arm blood pressures, a new diastolic decrescendo murmur consistent with aortic regurgitation, widened mediastinum on chest x‑ray, and long‑standing hypertension—is classic for an acute aortic dissection. Myocarditis would more commonly follow a viral prodrome, cause diffuse ECG/ST changes or heart failure signs, and would not explain unequal arm pressures or a widened mediastinum.

question: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a fall. He has been seen by the triage nurse but has not been evaluated by a physician. He is heard yelling down the hallway, requesting to speak to “whoever is in charge.” He refuses to talk to the emergency resident and insists on talking to the attending physician despite being informed that the attending is currently resuscitating a patient who was in a car accident. He says that he deserves better treatment because he has made numerous contributions to the field of medicine. When asked about his work, he mentions that he was a medical device salesman. He is accompanied by his wife, who appears embarrassed. She claims that her husband frequently makes a scene and apologizes for her husband's behavior. On mental status examination, the patient is oriented to person, place, and time. He appears agitated and speaks in short, pressured sentences. There is no disorder of thought process or content. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Acute stress disorder B. Antisocial personality disorder C. Obsessive compulsive personality disorder D. Borderline personality disorder E. Histrionic personality disorder F. Intermittent explosive disorder G. Bipolar disorder H. Narcissistic personality disorder
default:
Narcissistic personality disorder.

Rationale: His persistent grandiosity (inflated claims about contributions), entitlement (demands special treatment/speak to the attending), attention-seeking/agitation, and long-standing pattern reported by his wife fit narcissistic personality disorder. This is more consistent than an acute manic episode (no mood elevation, episodic course) or histrionic personality (more theatrical and rapidly shifting affect rather than entitlement/grandiosity).
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Narcissistic personality disorder.

Reasoning: He demonstrates a pervasive pattern of grandiosity and entitlement (insisting on speaking to the attending, claiming special contributions deserve preferential treatment), need for recognition, and lack of concern for his wife's embarrassment. There are no signs of the preoccupation with order, perfectionism, or control that characterize obsessive–compulsive personality disorder.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Narcissistic personality disorder.

Reasoning: His demand for special treatment, grandiose claim of major contributions, sense of entitlement (insisting on the attending), and a long-standing pattern of making scenes (wife’s comment) fit narcissistic personality traits. There is no persistent mood elevation, decreased need for sleep, or other features to support mania, and no thought-disorder/psychosis. Histrionic disorder is less likely because his behavior centers on superiority/entitlement rather than theatrical or sexually provocative attention-seeking.
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: narcissistic personality disorder.

Reasoning: He shows long-standing grandiosity and entitlement (insisting on speaking to the attending, claiming special contributions to medicine) with interpersonal problems (wife embarrassed, apologizing) that appear chronic rather than a new change. He is alert, oriented, and coherent (argues against delirium or an acute psychotic disorder), and there are no other manic features (no pervasive elevated mood, decreased need for sleep, or markedly disorganized behavior) to support mania. Histrionic or antisocial traits are less consistent than narcissistic features here.
raw_d:
Most likely diagnosis: Narcissistic personality disorder.

He demonstrates grandiosity and entitlement (insists on special treatment, claims major contributions), seeks preferential attention/admiration (demands the attending), and behaves arrogantly while his wife apologizes—classic narcissistic features. There is no evidence of the perfectionism, rigidity, preoccupation with rules/order, or control that define obsessive–compulsive personality disorder, and he is oriented and coherent (making delirium unlikely).

question:
A 30-year-old patient comes to the emergency room with a chief complaint of left chest pain and a productive cough with purulent sputum for 1 week. He also complains of shortness of breath. He said he had been previously diagnosed with influenza but did not follow the doctor’s instructions. His vitals include: heart rate 70/min, respiratory rate 22/min, temperature 38.7°C (101.7°F), blood pressure 120/60 mm Hg, and SO2 80%. His hemogram and chest X-ray findings are as follows:
Hemoglobin 14 mg/dL
Hematocrit 45%
Leukocyte count 12,000/mm3
Neutrophils 82%
Lymphocytes 15%
Monocytes 3%
Platelet count 270,000/mm3
Chest X-ray alveolar infiltrates in the left base with air bronchograms
What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Sarcoidosis B. Pneumonia C. Histoplasmosis D. Lung cancer E. Tuberculosis
default: Most likely a secondary bacterial lobar pneumonia (community-acquired lobar consolidation) following influenza — classically due to Staphylococcus aureus. Findings supporting this: fever, purulent sputum, neutrophilic leukocytosis, hypoxia and an alveolar consolidation with air bronchograms on CXR.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Acute lobar (bacterial) pneumonia — likely a post‑influenza secondary bacterial pneumonia (e.g., S. pneumoniae or Staphylococcus aureus).

Reasoning: Acute febrile illness with purulent sputum, shortness of breath, hypoxia and leukocytosis with neutrophilia fits bacterial pneumonia. Chest X‑ray showing alveolar consolidation with air bronchograms at the left base is classic for lobar/segmental consolidation. This presentation and temporal relation to influenza make bacterial superinfection far more likely than lung cancer (which is typically more indolent and shows a mass rather than acute air‑bronchogram consolidation).
raw_b:
Most likely acute lobar (bacterial) pneumonia — a secondary bacterial pneumonia after influenza.

Reasoning: fever, pleuritic chest pain, purulent productive cough, hypoxemia, neutrophilic leukocytosis and a chest x‑ray showing alveolar consolidation with air bronchograms are classic for lobar pneumonia (often Streptococcus pneumoniae or post‑influenza secondary bacterial infection).
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: acute bacterial lobar pneumonia of the left lower lobe — a post‑influenza secondary bacterial pneumonia (commonly S. aureus or S. pneumoniae).

Reason: acute fever, productive purulent cough and dyspnea, neutrophilic leukocytosis, hypoxemia (SpO2 80%) and chest x‑ray showing alveolar consolidation with air bronchograms are classic for lobar/segmental bacterial pneumonia; prior influenza increases risk of secondary bacterial superinfection.
raw_d:
Most likely diagnosis: acute lobar (bacterial) pneumonia of the left lower lung — not lung cancer.

Reasoning: acute 1‑week history with fever and purulent cough after influenza, marked hypoxemia (SpO2 80%), leukocytosis with neutrophilia, and a chest x‑ray showing alveolar consolidation with air bronchograms — a classic pattern for lobar/airspace pneumonia. Lung cancer typically presents more insidiously, often as a focal mass/nodule rather than air‑space consolidation, is less likely at age 30, and would not usually produce this acute febrile neutrophilic picture. If the patient fails to improve with appropriate antibiotics or imaging shows a discrete mass, pursue CT chest and further oncologic/bronchoscopic evaluation.

question: A 27-year-old woman presents to your office complaining of difficulty swallowing, and she describes that "there is something in the back of her throat". Furthermore, she also feels an "achy" chest pain that has been getting progressively worse over the last few weeks. She denies having any fever, shortness of breath, cough, abdominal pain, heartburn, nausea, or vomiting. The patient has a history of wrist fracture as a child, migraines, and a recent diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Benign tumor of the thymus B. Superior vena cava syndrome C. Anaplastic thyroid cancer D. Mediastinitis E. Thyroglossal duct cyst
default: Most likely a thymoma — an anterior mediastinal mass associated with myasthenia gravis causing compressive symptoms (sensation in the throat/odynophagia and progressive chest discomfort).
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: thymoma (an anterior mediastinal mass).

Reasoning: new myasthenia gravis in an adult is classically associated with a thymoma. Thymomas can produce progressive retrosternal/achy chest pain and cause compressive symptoms (dysphagia, globus sensation) from an anterior mediastinal mass. A thyroglossal duct cyst is typically a midline neck mass in children/young adults that moves with tongue protrusion and would not explain progressive chest pain or the strong MG association. Recommend chest imaging (CXR and contrast chest CT) to evaluate the anterior mediastinum.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: thymic hyperplasia (enlarged thymus associated with myasthenia gravis), not a “benign thymic tumor.”

Reasoning: new MG in a young woman is classically due to thymic hyperplasia (lymphoid hyperplasia) rather than thymoma, which is more typical in older adults and can be invasive. The dysphagia/globus and progressive anterior chest discomfort can reflect mass effect from an enlarged thymus or bulbar weakness from MG, so the correct association in this age group is thymic hyperplasia rather than a benign thymic neoplasm.
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: thymoma (an anterior mediastinal thymic epithelial tumor) associated with her myasthenia gravis.

Reasoning: Thymoma is classically linked to myasthenia gravis and can produce local compressive symptoms (sensation in the throat, dysphagia, anterior chest discomfort) as it enlarges. Next step would be imaging (contrast chest CT) to confirm an anterior mediastinal mass.
raw_d:
Most likely diagnosis: thymoma (anterior mediastinal mass).

Reasoning: her new diagnosis of myasthenia gravis is classically associated with a thymic neoplasm. A thymoma can produce progressive chest pain and mass-effect symptoms such as dysphagia and a “globus” sensation in the throat. A thyroglossal duct cyst usually presents as a midline neck lump that moves with tongue protrusion and wouldn’t explain chest pain or the MG association. Imaging (chest radiograph/CT) would be the next step to confirm.

question: A 6-year-old girl presents to her pediatrician with a rash and intermittent abdominal pain and swelling of her legs and arms. She has also begun to complain of pain in her knees and hands with no history of trauma. Her temperature is 97.6°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 100/80 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A as well as symmetric swelling in the joints of the upper extremities. Her abdomen is currently nontender and not painful. Laboratory studies are pending, and the results of a urinalysis are notable only for positive blood and protein in the urine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Hemorrhagic adrenalitis B. Henoch-Schonlein purpura C. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura D. Kawasaki disease E. Rubella
default: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (IgA-mediated small-vessel vasculitis). The classic triad — palpable purpuric rash (usually buttocks/legs), arthralgias, and abdominal pain — plus hematuria/proteinuria from IgA nephropathy fits this presentation.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Henoch–Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis).

Reasoning: Classic pediatric triad of palpable purpuric rash (typically on buttocks/legs), migratory arthralgias/arthritis, and intermittent abdominal pain, with renal involvement evidenced by hematuria and proteinuria. Hemorrhagic adrenalitis (bilateral adrenal hemorrhage) presents with acute shock, severe hypotension, fever and adrenal insufficiency and does not fit this subacute, localized rash + joint/abdominal/renal picture. Management is supportive and close renal/BP monitoring; consider steroids for severe abdominal or renal disease.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: IgA vasculitis (Henoch–Schönlein purpura).

Reason: a young child with a palpable purpuric rash (classically on buttocks/legs—Figure A), migratory arthralgias/arthritis, intermittent abdominal pain, and renal involvement with hematuria/proteinuria is the classic presentation of IgA-mediated small‑vessel vasculitis (HSP).
raw_c:
Diagnosis: Henoch–Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis).

Reasoning: This 6‑year‑old has the classic tetrad — palpable purpuric rash on the buttocks/legs (Figure A), migratory arthralgias/arthritis of knees/hands, intermittent abdominal pain, and renal involvement (hematuria and proteinuria). Normal vitals and the distribution/quality of the rash (palpable purpura) argue against ITP or systemic infection; IgA deposition in small vessels and mesangium explains the findings.
raw_d:
Henoch-Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis).

Reason: The classic pediatric tetrad—palpable purpuric rash (classically on buttocks/legs), migratory arthralgias, intermittent abdominal pain, and renal involvement with hematuria/proteinuria—fits this case. The child is otherwise not toxic and hemodynamically stable; hemorrhagic adrenalitis (acute bilateral adrenal hemorrhage) typically presents with severe illness, fever, shock and adrenal insufficiency, which are absent here.

question: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of daytime sleepiness and dry mouth for one month. She says her sleepiness is due to getting up to urinate several times each night. She noticed increased thirst about a month ago and now drinks up to 20 cups of water daily. She does not feel a sudden urge prior to urinating and has not had dysuria. She has a history of multiple urinary tract infections and head trauma following a suicide attempt 3 months ago. She has bipolar I disorder and hypertension. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Examination shows poor skin turgor. Mucous membranes are dry. Expiratory wheezes are heard over both lung fields. There is no suprapubic tenderness. She describes her mood as “good” and her affect is appropriate. Neurologic examination shows tremor in both hands. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 151 mEq/L and an elevated antidiuretic hormone. Urine osmolality is 124 mOsm/kg H2O. What is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
options: A. Hypothalamic injury B. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome C. Paraneoplastic syndrome D. Pituitary neoplasm E. Hyperthyroidism F. Psychogenic polydipsia G. Primary hyperaldosteronism H. History of urinary tract infections I. Mood stabilizer intake
default: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus from chronic lithium therapy for her bipolar disorder. The elevated ADH with very dilute urine indicates renal resistance to ADH (not central DI). Lithium (causes tremor) accumulates in collecting‑duct principal cells and impairs the cAMP/AQP2 response to ADH, producing polyuria, polydipsia and hypernatremia.
raw_a:
Most likely: lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Reasoning: Her polyuria/polydipsia with hypernatremia, low urine osmolality (124) despite an elevated ADH indicates renal resistance to ADH (nephrogenic DI). Lithium treatment for bipolar disorder commonly causes nephrogenic DI by impairing aquaporin-2 insertion in collecting duct principal cells and also causes tremor, which she has. Head trauma would cause central DI (low ADH), and primary polydipsia typically does not produce hypernatremia.
raw_b:
Most likely: lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Reasoning: She has polyuria/polydipsia, hypernatremia, dilute urine (Uosm 124) with elevated ADH — consistent with appropriate ADH secretion but renal resistance to it (nephrogenic DI). Her history of bipolar disorder and bilateral hand tremor strongly suggests lithium use, which classically produces nephrogenic DI by impairing ADH action in the collecting duct. Head trauma or a pituitary neoplasm would cause central DI with low ADH, so those are much less likely.
raw_c:
Most likely lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Reasoning: She has hypernatremia with inappropriately dilute urine (Uosm 124) despite an elevated ADH — this indicates end-organ (renal) resistance to ADH, not central DI. Her bipolar disorder and bilateral hand tremor point to lithium use, which commonly causes nephrogenic DI by impairing collecting‑duct response (reducing AQP2 insertion), producing polyuria/polydipsia and hypernatremia.
raw_d:
Most likely: nephrogenic diabetes insipidus from lithium (mood‑stabilizer) therapy.

Reasoning: she has polyuria/polydipsia with hypernatremia and a low urine osmolality despite an elevated ADH level — consistent with renal resistance to ADH (nephrogenic DI). Lithium (used for bipolar I) commonly causes this by impairing collecting‑duct response (and tremor is a classic lithium side effect). Head trauma/central DI would show low ADH, so pituitary lesion is unlikely.

question:
A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, he is alert, has mild chest pain, and minimal shortness of breath. He has one episode of vomiting in the hospital. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 90/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his trunk and right upper extremity. There are coarse breath sounds over the right lung base. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallop. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun. He subsequently develops increasing shortness of breath. Arterial blood gas analysis on 60% oxygen shows:
pH 7.36
pCO2 39 mm Hg
pO2 68 mm Hg
HCO3- 18 mEq/L
O2 saturation 81%
An x-ray of the chest shows patchy, irregular infiltrates over the right lung fields. What is the most likely diagnosis?"
options: A. Pneumothorax B. Tracheobronchial injury C. Pulmonary contusion D. Pulmonary embolism E. Aspiration pneumonia F. Hemothorax G. Acute respiratory distress syndrome
default:
Pulmonary contusion of the right lung.

Reason: after high‑speed blunt chest trauma you get patchy, unilateral alveolar hemorrhage/edema producing infiltrates and severe hypoxemia refractory to supplemental O2 (large A–a gradient), which fits this presentation better than ARDS, cardiogenic edema, pneumothorax, or aspiration.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: pulmonary (lung) contusion from blunt chest trauma.

Reasoning: after high-speed blunt trauma he has localized chest findings and chest x-ray with patchy, irregular alveolar infiltrates in the right lung and hypoxemia that is poorly corrected by supplemental O2 — a pattern typical of pulmonary contusion (alveolar hemorrhage/edema with shunt physiology). Hemothorax would produce a layering pleural fluid density and dullness/decreased breath sounds rather than patchy parenchymal infiltrates.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: aspiration pneumonitis (aspiration of gastric contents) causing right‑lung chemical pneumonitis.

Reasoning: he vomited in the hospital and then developed progressive dyspnea with hypoxemia not corrected by 60% O2 and patchy, irregular infiltrates confined to the right lung — a classic pattern for aspiration into the dependent right lung. Pulmonary contusion is possible after blunt trauma but would usually be temporally related to the impact and not specifically preceded by an emesis event.
raw_c:
Pulmonary contusion is the most likely diagnosis.

Reasoning: high‑speed blunt chest trauma with localized right‑sided chest wall abrasions and coarse breath sounds, plus the chest x‑ray showing patchy, irregular right‑sided alveolar opacities and severe hypoxemia (PaO2/FiO2 ≈113) point to alveolar hemorrhage/edema from pulmonary contusion. The hypoxemia that doesn’t correct with O2 reflects intrapulmonary shunt from contused lung. Aspiration is less likely because the vomiting occurred after arrival and the clinical picture and trauma distribution favor direct lung injury; pneumothorax/hemothorax would give different exam/x‑ray findings.
raw_d:
Pulmonary contusion is the most likely diagnosis.

Reasoning: the chest x-ray shows patchy, irregular alveolar opacities localized to the injured lung (classic for contusion), and the patient has hypoxemia that is poorly corrected on high FiO2 (shunt/V–Q mismatch from alveolar hemorrhage/edema). Contusions often worsen after fluid resuscitation. By contrast a hemothorax produces a homogeneous pleural layering/mass effect with dullness and diminished breath sounds, not focal patchy infiltrates with coarse breath sounds.

question: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of altered mental status for 2 hours. She and her husband were at the grocery store when she suddenly could not remember why she was there or how she got there. She has not had any head trauma. She has a history of depression and migraines. She does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine each night with dinner. She takes fluoxetine daily. She appears distressed and anxious. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is fully alert and oriented to self and place but not to time. Every few minutes she asks how she got to the emergency department. She is able to follow commands and sustain attention. She recalls 3/3 objects immediately and recalls 0/3 objects at 5 minutes. The remainder of the neurological exam shows no abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Transient global amnesia B. Hypoglycemia C. Depersonalization/derealization disorder D. Seizure E. Delirium F. Dissociative amnesia G. Alzheimer's disease H. Migraine
default:
Transient global amnesia (TGA).

Reason: sudden-onset isolated anterograde memory loss with repetitive questioning, preserved personal identity, attention and neurologic exam, and no focal deficits—classic for TGA (typically transient, resolving within 24 hours).
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: transient global amnesia (TGA).

Reasoning: sudden-onset isolated anterograde amnesia with repetitive questioning, preserved personal identity and attention, intact immediate recall but impaired delayed recall, no focal neurologic deficits, and a transient course (hours) are classic for TGA. Migraine, TIA, and seizure are less consistent with the pattern of isolated prolonged anterograde memory loss without other neurologic signs.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: transient global amnesia (TGA).

Reasoning: She has the classic sudden-onset isolated anterograde amnesia with repetitive questioning, preserved consciousness/attention and personal identity, normal neurologic exam, and a short-duration episode (hours) in a 60‑year‑old — exactly the TGA pattern. This presentation is less consistent with TIA (would usually have focal deficits), complex partial seizure (typically briefer with automatisms or postictal confusion), or psychogenic amnesia/dissociative fugue (would affect autobiographical identity).
raw_c:
Transient global amnesia (TGA).

She has the classic sudden-onset isolated anterograde amnesia with repetitive questioning, preserved consciousness/attention and personal identity, no focal neurologic signs, and a short duration (here ~2 hours) — all typical of TGA, which usually occurs in middle-aged/older adults and resolves within 24 hours. Seizure is less likely because she is alert and sustaining attention without a postictal state; TIA would usually produce focal deficits; psychogenic/fugue states typically affect identity and have different memory patterns.
raw_d:
No — the most likely diagnosis is transient global amnesia (TGA).

Reasoning: sudden isolated anterograde amnesia with repetitive questioning, preserved consciousness/attention and ability to follow commands, intact immediate recall but impaired delayed recall, normal focal neurologic exam, and short symptom duration (hours) are classic for TGA in a 60‑year‑old. Migraine is less likely because there is no headache or typical focal aura and attention/awareness are usually more disturbed with seizure/delirium; TIAs/seizures would more often produce focal signs or altered responsiveness.

question:
A 40-year-old man visits the office with complaints of fever and abdominal pain for the past 6 days. He is also concerned about his weight loss as he weighs 3.6 kg (8 lb) less, today, than he did 2 months ago. He has a previous history of being admitted to the hospital for recurrent cholangitis. The vital signs include: heart rate 97/min, respiratory rate 17/min, temperature 39.0°C (102.2°F), and blood pressure 114/70 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is tenderness on palpation of the right upper quadrant. The laboratory results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 16 g/dL
Hematocrit 44%
Leukocyte count 18,000/mm3
Neutrophils  60%
Bands 4%
Eosinophils 2%
Basophils 1%
Lymphocytes  27%
Monocytes 6%
Platelet count 345,000/mm3
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)  57 IU/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 70 IU/L
Alkaline phosphatase 140 U/L
Total bilirubin 8 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 5 mg/dL
An ultrasound is also done to the patient which is shown in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Hepatocarcinoma B. Liver abscess C. Hepatitis B D. Acute cholecystitis E. Cholangitis
default: Caroli disease — congenital (saccular) dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts (visible as cystic/“central dot” dilations on ultrasound), which causes recurrent cholangitis and predisposes to stones and cholangiocarcinoma.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Pyogenic (bacterial) liver abscess — hepatic abscess from a biliary source (ascending cholangitis).

Reasoning: Fever, RUQ pain, leukocytosis and cholestatic LFTs with marked direct hyperbilirubinemia in a patient with prior recurrent cholangitis strongly point to a biliary-source liver abscess. Ultrasound typically shows a hypoechoic/complex fluid collection with internal echoes consistent with an abscess. Management: blood cultures, IV broad‑spectrum antibiotics and percutaneous drainage.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Pyogenic (bacterial) liver abscess — hepatic abscess from ascending biliary infection.

Reasoning: Fever, RUQ pain, leukocytosis and jaundice in a patient with prior recurrent cholangitis fit a biliary-source hepatic abscess. The ultrasound (focal hypoechoic/fluid collection in the liver) is classic for an abscess rather than diffuse bile-duct dilation. Acute cholangitis produces biliary dilatation and systemic signs (Charcot triad) but would not show a focal intrahepatic fluid collection. Next steps: contrast CT for extent and percutaneous drainage plus broad-spectrum IV antibiotics targeting biliary organisms.
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: hilar cholangiocarcinoma (Klatskin tumor) causing obstructive jaundice with secondary/recurrent cholangitis.

Reasoning: middle‑aged man with weight loss and progressive cholestatic labs (↑bilirubin, ↑ALP), fever/RUQ pain and leukocytosis from ascending cholangitis, and a history of recurrent cholangitis (a risk setting for obstruction/strictures). Ultrasound findings in this context are most consistent with a hilar biliary mass producing proximal intrahepatic ductal dilation — classic for a Klatskin cholangiocarcinoma.
raw_d:
Most likely diagnosis: Pyogenic liver abscess.

Reasoning: The patient has fever, RUQ pain, leukocytosis and weight loss with a history of recurrent cholangitis (a risk factor for ascending biliary seeding). The ultrasound shows a focal complex cystic hepatic lesion (consistent with an abscess rather than diffuse biliary dilation seen in uncomplicated cholangitis). The jaundice and cholestatic enzymes can occur with concomitant biliary obstruction or inflammation. Next steps would be blood cultures, hepatic imaging with contrast CT for characterization, and percutaneous drainage plus broad‑spectrum IV antibiotics targeted to culture results.

question: A 55-year-old African American male presents to his primary care physician with complaints of persistent back pain and fatigue over 12 months. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 190/150 mm Hg, and laboratory tests reveal hyperlipidemia and a serum creatinine level of 3.0 mg/dL. 4.5 g of protein are excreted in the urine over 24 hours. Renal biopsy shows eosinophilic, acellular material in the glomerular tuft and capillary walls that display apple green-colored birefringence in polarized light upon Congo red tissue staining. The patient most likely suffers from which of the following:
options: A. Membranous nephropathy B. Focal segmental glomerular sclerosis C. Drug-induced acute tubular necrosis D. Multiple myeloma E. Malignant hypertension
default:
Primary (AL) amyloidosis from a plasma cell dyscrasia — most likely multiple myeloma.

Reason: Congo red–positive (apple‑green birefringence) amyloid in glomeruli with nephrotic‑range proteinuria, renal failure and bone/back pain fits light‑chain (AL) amyloidosis from multiple myeloma (Bence‑Jones proteins).
raw_a:
Conclusion: Renal amyloidosis (most likely AL amyloidosis from multiple myeloma), not membranous nephropathy.

Reasoning: Congo red–positive, apple‑green birefringent, eosinophilic, acellular deposits in glomeruli are diagnostic of amyloid. The nephrotic‑range proteinuria, renal failure and chronic back pain (suggesting possible myeloma bone disease) fit AL (primary) amyloidosis from a plasma cell dyscrasia, whereas membranous nephropathy shows subepithelial immune complex deposits, not Congo red positivity.
raw_b:
He most likely has AL (primary) amyloidosis from a plasma‑cell dyscrasia (eg, multiple myeloma).

Reasoning: Congo red–positive, apple‑green birefringent deposits in glomeruli indicate amyloid. Nephrotic‑range proteinuria, renal failure and systemic symptoms (back pain, fatigue—consistent with bone pain/anemia from plasma‑cell disease) point to light‑chain (AL) amyloidosis produced by monoclonal plasma cells. AA (inflammatory) amyloid is less likely without a chronic inflammatory disorder.
raw_c:
Primary (AL) amyloidosis from a plasma-cell dyscrasia (eg, multiple myeloma).

Reason: Congo red with apple‑green birefringence = amyloid deposition. Heavy proteinuria and renal failure reflect glomerular amyloid; the history of back pain and fatigue in a 55‑yo man is consistent with an underlying monoclonal plasma‑cell disorder producing light chains (AL amyloid), classically seen with multiple myeloma.
raw_d:
The most likely diagnosis is renal amyloidosis (AL amyloid) secondary to multiple myeloma — not membranous nephropathy.

Reasoning: Congo red with apple‑green birefringence is diagnostic of amyloid deposition (eosinophilic, acellular deposits in glomeruli/capillary walls). The patient’s heavy proteinuria, renal dysfunction and chronic back pain (suggesting lytic bone disease) fit multiple myeloma–related AL (light‑chain) amyloidosis. Membranous nephropathy shows subepithelial immune complex "spike‑and‑dome" changes and granular IgG/C3 on IF, and is Congo red negative.

question: A 75-year-old woman presents with a sudden onset of weakness and difficulty walking. She also complains of nausea and palpitations. She was working in her garden about an hour ago when her problems started. The patient says she is feeling warm even though the emergency room is air-conditioned. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder (MDD), diagnosed 5 years ago, hypertension, and osteoporosis. Current medications are aspirin, lisinopril, alendronate, calcium, venlafaxine, and a vitamin D supplement. Her pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is are 22/min, and blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. A noncontrast CT scan of the head, electrocardiogram (ECG), and routine laboratory tests are all normal. What most likely accounts for this patient’s condition?
options: A. Ischemic stroke B. Dehydration due to physical activity C. Aspirin overdose D. Missed dose of venlafaxine E. Missed dose of lisinopril
default: An acute ischemic stroke — most likely a thromboembolic occlusion of a posterior (vertebrobasilar) cerebral artery. Ischemic infarcts often produce sudden focal neurologic signs (ataxia, gait difficulty, nausea) and can have a normal noncontrast head CT in the first hours.
raw_a:
Conclusion: Her symptoms most likely represent venlafaxine (SNRI) discontinuation syndrome from a missed dose.

Reasoning: Venlafaxine has a relatively short half‑life and abrupt missed doses commonly cause withdrawal—dizziness/imbalance or ataxia, nausea, palpitations, diaphoresis/heat intolerance and anxiety/tachycardia—often with normal CT/ECG/labs. The timing (sudden onset while gardening) and normal workup fit antidepressant discontinuation rather than stroke or cardiac disease.
raw_b:
Most likely: an acute ischemic (embolic) stroke — probably posterior-circulation — from a cardiac embolus (eg, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation), not a missed dose of lisinopril.

Reasoning: sudden onset focal neurologic complaint (weakness, difficulty walking) with nausea/vertigo is typical of posterior‑circulation stroke. Noncontrast head CT is often normal early in ischemic stroke. Her palpitations and tachycardia point to an arrhythmic embolic source (paroxysmal AF can be missed on a single ECG). Hypertension is common acutely with stroke.
raw_c:
Most likely an acute posterior-circulation ischemic stroke (cerebellar infarct) causing sudden ataxia, nausea, and gait difficulty.

Reasoning: sudden onset focal neurologic deficit in an elderly hypertensive patient fits ischemia; cerebellar/brainstem strokes commonly produce nausea/vertigo and isolated gait weakness without cortical signs, and early noncontrast head CT can be normal for ischemic strokes.
raw_d:
Missed dose of venlafaxine (venlafaxine discontinuation syndrome) — most likely.

Reasoning: Venlafaxine is an SNRI with a short half‑life; abrupt omission can rapidly produce dizziness, gait disturbance/weakness, nausea, diaphoresis/feeling hot and palpitations from autonomic instability. Normal CT/ECG/labs and the acute onset while active make stroke/MI less likely and a missed lisinopril dose would not produce this constellation of neurologic and autonomic symptoms.

question: A 37-year-old G1P1001 delivers a male infant at 9 pounds 6 ounces after a C-section for preeclampsia with severe features. The mother has a history of type II diabetes with a hemoglobin A1c of 12.8% at her first obstetric visit. Before this pregnancy, she was taking metformin, and during this pregnancy, she was started on insulin. At her routine visits, her glucose logs frequently showed fasting fingerstick glucoses above 120 mg/dL and postprandial values above 180 mg/dL. In addition, her routine third trimester culture for group B Streptococcus was positive. At 38 weeks and 4 days gestation, she was found to have a blood pressure of 176/103 mmHg and reported a severe headache during a routine obstetric visit. She denied rupture of membranes or vaginal bleeding. Her physician sent her to the obstetric triage unit, and after failure of several intravenous doses of labetalol to lower her blood pressure and relieve her headache, a C-section was performed without complication. Fetal heart rate tracing had been reassuring throughout her admission. Apgar scores at 1 and 5 minutes were 7 and 10. After one hour, the infant is found to be jittery; the infant's temperature is 96.1°F (35.6°C), blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 60/min. When the first feeding is attempted, he does not latch and begins to shake his arms and legs. After 20 seconds, the episode ends and the infant becomes lethargic. What is the most likely cause of this infant’s presentation?
options: A. Transplacental action of maternal insulin B. ß-cell hyperplasia C. Neonatal sepsis D. Inborn error of metabolism E. Neonatal encephalopathy
default: Neonatal hypoglycemia from fetal hyperinsulinemia due to poorly controlled maternal diabetes. Maternal hyperglycemia → fetal islet cell hyperplasia and high insulin; after birth the glucose supply stops and the infant becomes hypoglycemic, causing jitteriness, poor feeding, tremors, and lethargy.
raw_a:
Correct — neonatal hypoglycemia from fetal pancreatic β‑cell hyperplasia (hyperinsulinemia).  

Maternal hyperglycemia crosses the placenta, chronically stimulating fetal insulin secretion and causing β‑cell hypertrophy/hyperplasia and high insulin levels. After delivery the maternal glucose supply stops but fetal insulin remains elevated, producing early neonatal hypoglycemia (jitteriness, poor feeding, tremors/seizures), especially in a macrosomic infant of a poorly controlled diabetic mother.
raw_b:
Conclusion: This infant most likely has neonatal hypoglycemia from fetal hyperinsulinemia due to poorly controlled maternal diabetes.

Reasoning: Maternal A1c 12.8% with frequent prenatal hyperglycemia and a macrosomic infant make fetal islet hyperplasia/hyperinsulinemia very likely. After delivery the sudden loss of maternal glucose exposes the infant to excess insulin, producing jitteriness, poor feeding, lethargy (and hypothermia can worsen glucose use). Neonatal encephalopathy (HIE) is unlikely given reassuring fetal heart tracing and Apgars 7 and 10. Check a bedside glucose immediately and treat (early feeding or IV dextrose if low).
raw_c:
Most likely neonatal hypoglycemia from fetal hyperinsulinemia due to poorly controlled maternal diabetes.

Reasoning: Large infant of a mother with very high A1c and frequent hyperglycemia is predisposed to fetal hyperinsulinemia; after delivery the sudden loss of maternal glucose supply causes hypoglycemia, which presents early with jitteriness, poor feeding and lethargy. This fits the timing (first hour) better than sepsis or drug effects. Check bedside glucose and treat promptly.
raw_d:
Conclusion: β-cell hyperplasia of the fetal pancreas causing neonatal hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia.

Reasoning: Maternal poorly controlled diabetes (A1c 12.8%) produced fetal hyperglycemia in utero, which stimulates fetal islet β-cell hyperplasia and insulin excess. After birth the maternal glucose supply stops but fetal insulin remains high → neonatal hypoglycemia, which classically presents with jitteriness, tremors, poor feeding and lethargy in a large-for-gestational-age infant. Reassuring fetal tracing and Apgars make hypoxic encephalopathy unlikely.

question: A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a fever and a headache. Her symptoms started yesterday and have rapidly progressed. Initially, she was experiencing just a fever and a headache which she was treating with acetaminophen. It rapidly progressed to blurry vision, chills, nausea, and vomiting. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension and she is currently taking insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and oral contraceptive pills. Her temperature is 104°F (40.0°C), blood pressure is 157/93 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Upon further inspection, the patient also demonstrates exophthalmos in the affected eye. The patient's extraocular movements are notably decreased in the affected eye with reduced vertical and horizontal gaze. The patient also demonstrates decreased sensation near the affected eye in the distribution of V1 and V2. While the patient is in the department waiting for a CT scan, she becomes lethargic and acutely altered. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Acute closed angle glaucoma B. Brain abscess C. Cavernous sinus thrombosis D. Periorbital cellulitis E. Intracranial hemorrhage
default:
Septic cavernous sinus thrombosis. 

Reason: acute high fever and severe headache with rapid progression to ipsilateral proptosis, ophthalmoplegia (III/IV/VI dysfunction), and loss of V1/V2 facial sensation — classic cavernous sinus involvement from an infectious thrombosis with intracranial extension (explaining lethargy). This is an emergency requiring urgent IV antibiotics, neurosurgical/ENT evaluation, and imaging (MRI/MR venography).
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: septic cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Reasoning: acute febrile illness with rapidly progressive headache, unilateral proptosis and painful ophthalmoplegia plus sensory loss in V1/V2 distribution points to involvement of cranial nerves III, IV, V1/V2, VI in the cavernous sinus. The rapid deterioration/altered mental status and fever favor an infectious thrombosis rather than intracranial hemorrhage. This is an emergency—diagnose with MRI/MRV or CT venography and start broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (and consider anticoagulation and surgical source control).
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Cavernous sinus thrombosis (septic).

Reasoning: Acute high fever with rapid progression, ipsilateral proptosis and ophthalmoplegia (impaired CN III, IV, VI function), and loss of V1/V2 sensation localize to the cavernous sinus. The systemic toxicity and acute altered mental status reflect intracranial extension/rapid progression. Orbital cellulitis or invasive fungal rhino‑orbital disease can mimic some features, but the combination of cranial nerve III/IV/VI palsies plus trigeminal (V1/V2) sensory loss and proptosis is classic for cavernous sinus thrombosis. Confirm with urgent contrast MRI/MRV or CT venography and begin broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and neurosurgical/ENT consultation.
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: septic cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Reasoning: acute high fever with rapidly progressive periorbital signs — proptosis (exophthalmos), painful ophthalmoplegia with reduced horizontal and vertical extraocular movements, and sensory loss in V1/V2 — localize to the cavernous sinus where CN III, IV, V1/V2 and VI run. Tachycardia, rapid deterioration to altered mental status, and diabetes (infection risk) favor an infectious thrombosis with intracranial extension. Orbital cellulitis can cause proptosis and limited eye movements but typically does not produce trigeminal sensory deficits or the cranial-nerve pattern seen here; stroke, myasthenia gravis, or isolated orbital apex disease are less consistent with the acute febrile, rapidly progressive septic picture.
raw_d:
The most likely diagnosis is cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Reasoning: the combination of acute fever and rapidly progressive orbital findings (exophthalmos, painful ophthalmoplegia with impaired vertical and horizontal gaze), sensory loss in the V1/V2 distributions, and systemic toxicity strongly points to a septic/thrombotic process of the cavernous sinus rather than an intracranial hemorrhage. Cavernous sinus thrombosis classically produces cranial nerve III, IV, V1/V2, and VI dysfunction with periorbital edema/proptosis and fever from a facial or sinus source; intracranial hemorrhage would more commonly present with focal cortical signs, sudden severe headache and altered consciousness but not the V1/V2 sensory loss and ocular nerve palsies with proptosis seen here. (Confirm with contrast CT venography or MR venography and start empiric IV antibiotics and anticoagulation/consult neurosurgery/ENT as indicated.)

question: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of tingling pain in the sole of his right foot when he raises it above chest level during exercises. He reports that he started exercising regularly 2 months ago and that his right calf cramps when he uses the incline feature on the treadmill, forcing him to take frequent breaks. The pain completely disappears after resting for a few minutes. He has an 8-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His only medication is metformin. His pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 170/92 mm Hg. Straight leg raise test elicits pallor and tingling pain in the right foot. There is no pain in the back. His muscle strength is normal. Femoral pulses are palpable; right pedal pulses are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options:
A. Femoropopliteal artery stenosis B. Diabetic neuropathy C. Vasculitis of the right popliteal artery D. Acute thrombosis of right popliteal vein E. Lumbar spinal stenosis F. Aortoiliac artery stenosis
"
default: Most likely peripheral arterial disease (atherosclerotic lower‑extremity ischemia) causing intermittent claudication of the right calf. Evidence: exertional calf pain relieved by rest, absent right pedal pulses, elevation‑induced pallor/paresthesia, and strong atherosclerotic risk factors (smoking, diabetes, HTN).
raw_a:
Correct — femoropopliteal (superficial femoral/popliteal) arterial occlusive disease causing peripheral arterial disease with intermittent claudication.

Reasoning: classic exertional calf cramping relieved by rest, absent pedal pulses with intact femoral pulses (lesion distal to femoral), elevation-induced pallor and paresthesia on straight-leg raise (ischemic, not neurogenic) and vascular risk factors (smoking, diabetes, HTN) point to atherosclerotic stenosis of the femoropopliteal segment.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: peripheral arterial disease (atherosclerotic intermittent claudication of the right lower extremity, e.g., femoropopliteal occlusive disease).

Reasoning: classic exertional calf cramping that is reproducibly relieved by rest, absent right pedal pulses, leg pallor/tingling with elevation, and strong atherosclerotic risk factors (smoking, diabetes, HTN) point to vascular ischemia. Neurogenic claudication from lumbar stenosis would usually have normal distal pulses, often back pain or positional relief with flexion, and not pallor on elevation.
raw_c:
Most likely peripheral arterial disease (atherosclerotic intermittent claudication) of the right lower extremity.

Reasoning: exertional calf cramping that reliably resolves with rest, absent right pedal pulses, and risk factors (long smoking history, diabetes, hypertension) point to arterial ischemia. Elevation-induced pallor/tingling (on straight‑leg raise) reflects reduced distal perfusion; findings are not consistent with neurogenic claudication/spinal stenosis (which usually preserves pulses, often has back symptoms, and is posture‑dependent in a different way).
raw_d:
Femoropopliteal peripheral arterial disease (arterial stenosis/occlusion) — peripheral vascular claudication.

Reason: Exertional calf cramping relieved quickly by rest, heavy smoking/diabetes/HTN risk factors, absent right pedal pulses with preserved femoral pulses (lesion distal to femoral), pain and pallor provoked by leg elevation (ischemic sign) and no back pain or neurologic deficit — findings point to arterial (femoropopliteal) rather than neurogenic (spinal) claudication.

question:
A 13-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents for 5 days of abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, and mild diarrhea. Her parents have been giving her acetaminophen in the past 3 days, which they stopped 24 hours ago when they noted blood in their daughter's urine. Upon admission, the patient has a fever of 39.6°C (103.3°F) and is hemodynamically stable. While waiting for the results of the laboratory tests, the patient develops intense left flank pain, and nausea and vomiting intensifies. Her condition rapidly deteriorates with an abnormally high blood pressure of 180/100 mm Hg, a heart rate of 120/min, and labored breathing leading to ventilatory failure. Under these conditions, the ER team immediately transfers the patient to the pediatric ICU, however, the patient dies shortly after. The pathologist shares with you some excerpts from her complete blood count and peripheral smear report:
Hemoglobin 7 mg/dL
Mean 14.0 g/dL (-2SD: 13.0 g/dL)
MCV 85 fL; 80–96 fL
Platelets 60,000; 150,000–450,000
Peripheral smear Schistocytes (+); Schistocytes (-)
White blood cells 12,900; 4,500–11,000
What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Antiphospholipid syndrome B. Sickle cell disease C. IgA nephropathy D. Hemolytic uremic syndrome E. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) nephropathy
default: The presentation is most consistent with typical (diarrhea-associated) hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) — acute microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes, Hb 7 g/dL), thrombocytopenia (platelets 60k) and acute renal involvement/hypertension following a diarrheal illness (classically E. coli O157:H7).
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: typical (diarrhea-associated) hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

Reasoning: the patient had a prodrome of diarrhea and fever followed by the classic triad of MAHA (schistocytes on smear, severe anemia), thrombocytopenia (platelets 60,000), and acute renal involvement (hematuria, flank pain, severe hypertension). This picture fits post‑infectious E. coli O157:H7–associated HUS; IgA nephropathy would not produce thrombocytopenia or schistocytes (microangiopathic hemolysis).
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: typical (diarrhea-associated) hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

Reasoning: classic triad is present — microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (severe anemia with schistocytes), thrombocytopenia (platelets 60,000), and acute renal involvement (hematuria, flank pain, acute hypertension). The illness began after a diarrheal prodrome in a child, and renal failure with hypertensive crisis explains the rapid pulmonary/ventilatory deterioration (pulmonary edema). TTP is less likely in a child and usually features prominent neurologic symptoms and severe ADAMTS13 deficiency; DIC would show overt consumptive coagulopathy (prolonged PT/PTT, bleeding) rather than an isolated MAHA/renal-predominant picture.
raw_c:
Yes — the most likely diagnosis is typical (diarrhea-associated) hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

Reasoning: the patient has the classic triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (severe anemia with schistocytes), thrombocytopenia (platelets 60,000), and acute renal injury (blood in urine, flank pain, severe hypertension), preceded by a diarrheal illness. The rapid fluid overload/pulmonary compromise and hypertension are typical complications of acute renal failure in HUS. TTP and DIC are less likely given the preceding diarrheal prodrome and predominant renal picture.
raw_d:
Most likely diagnosis: typical (diarrhea-associated) hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS).

Reasoning: the patient has the classic triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (marked anemia with schistocytes on smear), thrombocytopenia (platelets 60,000), and acute renal involvement with hematuria and abrupt hypertension — all following a prodrome of abdominal pain/diarrhea. The rapid pulmonary/ventilatory failure fits fluid overload/acute renal failure from severe HUS. IgA nephropathy would cause episodic hematuria (often after a URI), but does not produce thrombocytopenia, schistocytes, or the microangiopathic hemolysis seen here.

question: A 73-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute substernal chest pain that began a few hours ago. The pain is described as a “pressure” that radiates to his left arm. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is on chlorthalidone for his hypertension and simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He has a 30 pack-year history of smoking and drinks 1-2 beers on weekends. His EKG shows ST depressions in the anterior precordial leads and he is given the proper medications and sent for emergency revascularization. Seven days later, he develops dyspnea that worsens in the supine position. Bibasilar crackles are heard on pulmonary auscultation. Cardiac exam reveals a new 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border. What is the most likely etiology of this patient’s new symptoms?
options: A. Aortic stenosis B. Ventricular wall aneurysm C. Restrictive pericarditis D. Papillary muscle rupture E. Arrhythmia
default: Postinfarction ventricular septal rupture — macrophage-mediated degradation of necrotic septal myocardium 3–7 days after a transmural MI producing an acute left-to-right shunt. This causes pulmonary edema and a new holosystolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border.
raw_a:
The most likely etiology is a postinfarction ventricular septal rupture (acute VSD) causing an acute left→right shunt and pulmonary edema.

Reasoning: mechanical complications of MI classically occur 3–7 days after infarct when macrophage-mediated necrosis weakens myocardium. A new holosystolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border (not the apex) points to interventricular septal rupture. Papillary muscle rupture produces acute severe MR with a holosystolic murmur loudest at the apex radiating to the axilla and is more common after inferior MIs. Your patient’s anterior-wall infarct and murmur location fit VSD.
raw_b:
Most likely: postinfarction ventricular septal rupture (acute VSD) causing a sudden left-to-right shunt and acute heart failure.

Reasoning: A new holosystolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border 3–7 days after an MI is classic for septal rupture from macrophage-mediated breakdown of a transmural infarct. That produces acute pulmonary congestion/orthopnea from increased pulmonary blood flow and biventricular dysfunction. An arrhythmia wouldn’t explain the new harsh holosystolic murmur localized to the left sternal border.
raw_c:
Most likely a postinfarction ventricular septal rupture (VSD) causing an acute left-to-right shunt.

Reasoning: VSD from infarcted septum typically occurs 3–7 days after MI when macrophage-mediated tissue degradation weakens the wall. It produces sudden heart failure/pulmonary edema and a new holosystolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border (contrast: papillary muscle rupture causes mitral regurgitation with a murmur loudest at the apex radiating to the axilla).
raw_d:
The most likely etiology is a postinfarction ventricular septal rupture (VSD).

Reasoning: He developed acute dyspnea/pulmonary edema 3–7 days after MI with a new holosystolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border — classic for septal rupture producing an acute left-to-right shunt. Papillary muscle rupture causes acute severe MR but gives a holosystolic murmur loudest at the apex radiating to the axilla, not at the left sternal border. Mechanism: macrophage-mediated weakening of infarcted myocardium several days after transmural MI.

question: A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police after he was found running around a local park naked and screaming late at night. During intake, the patient talks non-stop about the government spying on him and his family, but provides little useful information besides his name and date of birth. Occasionally he refers to himself in the third person. He refuses to eat anything and will only drink clear fluids because he is afraid of being poisoned. A medical records search reveals that the patient has been treated for psychotic behavior and occasional bouts of severe depression for several years. Today, his heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 19/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, he appears gaunt and anxious. His heart has a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. CMP, CBC, and TSH are normal. A urine toxicology test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Bipolar 1 disorder B. Brief psychotic disorder C. Schizoaffective disorder D. Schizophrenia E. Major depression disorder
default:
Most likely schizoaffective disorder (depressive type). 

Rationale: he has chronic psychotic symptoms independent of mood episodes (years of psychosis) with intermittent severe depressive episodes. Normal labs/toxicology make substance- or medical-induced psychosis unlikely.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: schizoaffective disorder.

Reasoning: He has chronic psychotic symptoms treated for years (paranoid delusions, disorganized behavior, thought disturbance) with intermittent major depressive episodes. That pattern—psychosis present for substantial periods independent of mood episodes, plus concurrent mood episodes—fits schizoaffective disorder. (Bipolar I with psychotic features would require psychosis only during mood episodes; schizophrenia would lack the recurrent mood episodes.)
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Schizophrenia (paranoid-type features).

Reasoning: He has multi‑year persistent psychotic symptoms (persecutory delusions, disorganized behavior, third‑person references, poor self‑care) meeting the duration criteria for schizophrenia. His depressive episodes are described as occasional and not present for the majority of the illness, so this is not schizoaffective disorder (which requires mood symptoms to occupy a substantial portion of the total illness). Workup (CMP/CBC/TSH, tox) is negative for medical or substance causes. The presentation therefore best fits schizophrenia with prominent paranoid delusions.
raw_c:
Most likely schizoaffective disorder (depressive type).

Reason: He has long‑standing psychotic symptoms (persecutory delusions, disorganized behavior) that occur independently of mood episodes, plus intermittent episodes of major depression. That pattern — psychosis present outside of mood episodes plus recurrent major depressive episodes — fits schizoaffective disorder and distinguishes it from (1) major depressive disorder with psychotic features (psychosis only during mood episodes) and (2) primary schizophrenia (no significant mood episodes).
raw_d:
Most likely diagnosis: schizoaffective disorder.

Reasoning: he has chronic, long-standing psychotic symptoms with only intermittent episodes of major depression — and now has florid psychosis in the absence of a clear mood episode. That pattern (psychosis present for ≥2 weeks without mood symptoms, with mood episodes occurring for a substantial portion of the illness) fits schizoaffective disorder. Bipolar I with psychotic features would require psychosis tied to clear manic or depressive episodes (and a history of mania), which is not described here. Normal labs and negative tox further support a primary psychiatric diagnosis.

question: A man returns home late at night to find his 15-year-old son and 40-year-old wife unconscious in the family room. He immediately summons emergency services. In the field, pulse oximetry shows oxygen saturation at 100% for both patients. 100% yet they both appear cyanotic. Both patients are provided with 2L of oxygen by way of nasal cannula on the way to the hospital. An arterial blood gas is performed on the teenager and reveals pH of 7.35, PaCO2 of 31.8 mm Hg, PaO2 of 150 mm Hg, HCO3- of 20 mEq/L, SaO2 of 80%, and a COHb of 18%. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
options: A. Anemic hypoxia B. Diffusion-limited hypoxia C. Methemoglobinemia D. Carbon monoxide poisoning E. Ischemic hypoxia
default: Carbon monoxide poisoning (carboxyhemoglobinemia) from inhalation of combustion products (eg, faulty furnace or car exhaust). CO binds hemoglobin with high affinity, leaving PaO2 normal but reducing SaO2 and causing tissue hypoxia; pulse oximetry reads falsely high.
raw_a:
Conclusion: This is carbon monoxide poisoning (carboxyhemoglobinemia), not simple anemic hypoxia.

Reason: COHb is 18% on the ABG and PaO2 is high (150 mm Hg) despite cyanosis. Pulse oximeters read COHb as oxyhemoglobin and give falsely high SpO2 (seen as 100%), while CO binding to hemoglobin prevents O2 carriage/release, producing tissue hypoxia. The presentation (unconscious, cyanotic with normal PaO2 and elevated COHb) is classic for CO inhalation (eg, faulty heater, car exhaust, smoke).
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.

Reasoning: pulse oximeters cannot distinguish carboxyhemoglobin from oxyhemoglobin and will report falsely normal/high SpO2 (often near 100%) despite tissue hypoxia. The ABG shows a high PaO2 with a low measured SaO2 and an elevated COHb (18%) on co-oximetry — the pattern expected with CO binding to hemoglobin. The COHb may already have fallen after oxygen was started, so a lower value than expected for coma does not rule out significant prior exposure.
raw_c:
Most likely carbon monoxide poisoning causing elevated carboxyhemoglobin (COHb).

Reasoning: PaO2 is normal (dissolved O2 unaffected) but co-oximetry shows SaO2 80% and COHb 18%, indicating hemoglobin is bound by CO and unavailable for O2 transport. Standard pulse oximetry cannot distinguish oxyhemoglobin from carboxyhemoglobin and thus can read falsely high (here 100%) despite clinical cyanosis and impaired oxygen delivery. Methemoglobinemia would give a different pulse-ox pattern (~85%) and no elevated COHb.
raw_d:
Conclusion: The most likely cause is carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning.

Reasoning: The key findings—late-night simultaneous unconsciousness, cyanosis with pulse oximetry reading 100%, a high PaO2 (150 mmHg) with a low measured SaO2 (80%) and an elevated carboxyhemoglobin (COHb 18%)—are classic for CO poisoning. Pulse oximeters cannot distinguish oxyhemoglobin from carboxyhemoglobin and therefore give falsely normal/high SpO2 despite impaired O2 carriage. PaO2 reflects dissolved O2 (normal/high with supplemental O2), while COHb documents CO binding to hemoglobin and resultant tissue hypoxia. This fits CO exposure rather than simple anemic hypoxia.

question: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to his back during an altercation. He reports weakness and numbness of the lower extremities. He has no history of serious illness. On arrival, he is alert and cooperative. His pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm laceration on his back next to the vertebral column at the level of the T10 vertebra. Neurologic examination shows right-sided flaccid paralysis with a diminished vibratory sense ipsilaterally, decreased sensation to light touch at the level of his laceration and below, and left-sided loss of hot, cold, and pin-prick sensation at the level of the umbilicus and below. Deep tendon reflexes of his right lower extremity are 4+ and symmetrical. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Anterior cord syndrome B. Cauda equina syndrome C. Brown-Sequard syndrome D. Posterior cord syndrome E. Central cord syndrome
default: Brown-Séquard syndrome from a right-sided hemisection of the spinal cord at about T10. This explains ipsilateral (right) motor paralysis and loss of vibration/proprioception and contralateral (left) loss of pain/temperature below the lesion. (Early flaccidity can reflect spinal shock; long-term signs become spastic with hyperreflexia.)
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Right-sided Brown-Séquard syndrome (hemisection of the spinal cord at about T10).

Reasoning: The patient has ipsilateral (right) motor weakness and loss of vibration/proprioception — consistent with corticospinal tract and dorsal column damage on the same side — and contralateral (left) loss of pain and temperature beginning a few segments below the lesion (umbilicus ≈ T10), consistent with spinothalamic tract involvement after its contralateral crossing. A penetrating stab wound classically produces a hemisection. This pattern is inconsistent with anterior cord syndrome, which produces bilateral motor and pain/temperature loss with preserved dorsal-column modalities.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Brown‑Sequard syndrome from a right-sided hemisection of the spinal cord at about T10.

Reasoning: The wound is adjacent to T10 and the exam fits a hemisection — ipsilateral loss of motor function and vibration/proprioception (right-sided corticospinal and dorsal column involvement) with contralateral loss of pain and temperature beginning a level or two below the lesion (left spinothalamic tract). The sensory level at the umbilicus corresponds to T10. The apparently “flaccid” weakness and absent Babinski can be seen early after traumatic cord injury because of spinal shock; classic UMN signs (spasticity, upgoing toes) may develop later.
raw_c:
Diagnosis: Right-sided Brown-Sequard syndrome (hemisection of the spinal cord at about T10).

Reasoning: Ipsilateral (right) loss of motor function and vibratory/proprioceptive sensation indicates corticospinal tract and dorsal column damage on the right. Contralateral (left) loss of pain and temperature beginning at the umbilicus (T10 dermatome) fits spinothalamic tract involvement, which crosses within a couple segments above entry. The pattern is classic for a right hemisection at the T10 level. (Any initial flaccidity or absent Babinski can reflect the acute phase/spinal shock; hyperreflexia develops as the upper-motor–neuron picture becomes established.)
raw_d:
Brown-Sequard (right-sided hemisection) of the spinal cord.

Reason: Ipsilateral (right) motor weakness and loss of vibration/proprioception below the T10 level with contralateral (left) loss of pain and temperature below the umbilicus is the classic pattern of a hemisection. Anterior cord syndrome would produce bilateral motor and pain/temp loss with preserved vibration/proprioception (posterior columns spared), so it does not fit. The initial flaccidity and absent Babinski can reflect the acute phase/spinal shock; the later hyperreflexia supports an upper-motor neuron lesion.

question: A 7-year-old boy presents to an urgent care center for a rash that began approximately 2 days ago. According to his mother, it began as a pink rash on his face and has subsequently spread to his trunk. The child was adopted and has not yet begun care with his pediatrician. His temperature is 100.2°F (37.9°C), blood pressure is 104/74 mmHg, pulse is 99/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for the rash in Figure A and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy. The child is otherwise interactive and is quietly playing with toys. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Kawasaki disease B. Parvovirus C. Rubella D. Rubeola E. Roseola
default:
Rubella (German measles). 

Rationale: a mild, pink maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk with low‑grade fever and prominent postauricular/posterior cervical lymphadenopathy is classic for rubella (rubella virus). Ask about vaccination and counsel regarding exposure of pregnant contacts.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Rubella (German measles).

Reasoning: The child has a pink maculopapular rash that began on the face and spread to the trunk, low‑grade fever, and prominent posterior cervical/postauricular lymphadenopathy — a classic constellation for rubella, especially in an adopted/unvaccinated child. Kawasaki disease is unlikely because it requires ≥5 days of high fever plus mucocutaneous signs, conjunctivitis, and extremity changes, which are absent here.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) due to parvovirus B19.

Reasoning: a school‑aged child with a recent “slapped‑cheek” pink facial eruption that then spreads to the trunk with a lacy/reticular quality and only low‑grade fever is classic for erythema infectiosum. Rubella can present with a pink maculopapular face‑to‑trunk rash and posterior lymphadenopathy, but rubella lacks the distinctive slapped‑cheek and reticular trunk pattern seen here and usually has a different prodrome.
raw_c:
Rubella (German measles).

Reason: the child has a low‑grade fever and a pink maculopapular rash that began on the face and quickly spread to the trunk plus posterior cervical/postauricular lymphadenopathy — classic for rubella. The illness lacks the high fever, cough/coryza/conjunctivitis and Koplik spots of measles and does not have the “slapped‑cheek” reticulated rash of erythema infectiosum. Confirm with rubella IgM or PCR and ask about vaccination and any pregnant household contacts.
raw_d:
Rubella. 

The presentation—pink maculopapular rash that began on the face and rapidly spread to the trunk, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, mild low‑grade fever, and a generally well-appearing child—is classic for rubella. Kawasaki disease is unlikely because it requires high fever for ≥5 days plus other findings (conjunctivitis, oral mucous changes, extremity changes, polymorphous rash and/or significant cervical lymphadenopathy in a younger child); this child has only 2 days of mild fever and lacks the mucocutaneous and systemic features of Kawasaki.

question: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department from his home complaining of dyspnea. He is alert and oriented. The following arterial blood gas readings are drawn: pH: 7.33 (Normal: 7.35-7.45), pCO2: 70 mmHg (Normal: 35-45 mmHg), HCO3 33 (Normal: 21-26 mEq/L) What is most likely to have produced this patient’s condition?
options: A. Panic attack B. Mechanical ventilation C. Diabetic ketoacidosis D. Pulmonary embolus E. Chronic obstructive bronchitis
default: This is chronic respiratory acidosis (primary ↑pCO2 causing acidemia) with metabolic (renal) compensation (elevated HCO3). The pattern is most consistent with chronic CO2 retention from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (eg, emphysema/chronic bronchitis).
raw_a:
