Decreased thumb sensation reflects involvement of the median nerve trunk or neurapraxia in the same distribution. Pulses are intact, which rules out frank vascular compromise but does not exclude the fracture/nerve injury.
raw_c:
Most likely a supracondylar fracture of the distal humerus with median nerve (including anterior interosseous branch) injury.

Reasoning: a fall on an outstretched hand in a child, crepitus just above the elbow and inability to use the arm point to a distal humeral (supracondylar) fracture. The inability to make the “OK” sign indicates anterior interosseous (motor) dysfunction, and decreased thumb sensation indicates involvement of the median nerve — injuries commonly seen with supracondylar fractures. Pulses are intact, so brachial artery compromise is not evident.
raw_d:
Most likely: a supracondylar (distal) humerus fracture with median/ anterior interosseous nerve injury.

Reason: FOOSH in a 7‑year‑old, crepitus just above the elbow and pain with elbow motion localize to the distal humerus (supracondylar). The inability to make the “OK” sign reflects anterior interosseous nerve (median branch) motor loss (flexor pollicis longus/flexor digitorum profundus), and thumb sensory changes point to median nerve involvement — a classic complication of supracondylar fractures. A mid‑shaft humeral fracture would more commonly injure the radial nerve (wrist drop), not produce an AIN/median pattern.

question:
A 75-year-old woman is brought by a patrolman to the emergency department because of altered mental status. She was found wandering next to the highway. The patient was unable to answer questions and collapsed in transit. Her vitals are: temperature, 33.0°C (91.4°F); pulse, 40/min; respirations,12/min; blood pressure, 80/50 mm Hg; and oxygen saturation, 85% on room air. Physical examination shows decorticate posturing, incomprehensible speech, eyes opening to pain, dry hair, coarse and waxy skin, and non-pitting edema around the face and all extremities. Electrocardiogram shows sinus bradycardia. Laboratory studies show:
Calcium 9.0 mg/dL
Hematocrit (female) 34%
Potassium 4.0 mEq/L
Sodium 120 mEq/L
TSH 110.0 µU/mL
Thyroxine (T4) 1.2 µg/dL
Triiodothyronine (T3) 70 ng/dL
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
options: A. Myxedema coma B. Pheochromocytoma crisis C. Septic shock D. Tertiary hyperparathyroidism E. Thyroid storm
default:
Myxedema coma from severe primary hypothyroidism. 

Rationale: profound hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, hyponatremia, altered mental status and nonpitting myxedematous edema with an extremely elevated TSH (primary hypothyroidism) and low T3 are classic for myxedema coma.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: myxedema coma due to severe primary hypothyroidism.

Reasoning: Marked elevation of TSH (110 µU/mL) with low T3/T4 indicates primary hypothyroidism. The patient’s hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, hypoventilation, altered mental status/coma, hyponatremia, and nonpitting “waxy” edema (myxedema) fit myxedema coma. Tertiary hyperparathyroidism is incorrect and unrelated to these thyroid findings. Immediate treatment is supportive care plus IV thyroid hormone and stress‑dose glucocorticoids.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: myxedema coma (severe, decompensated primary hypothyroidism).

Reasoning: The patient has classic features of life‑threatening hypothyroidism — profound hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, altered mental status/coma, hyponatremia, non‑pitting “myxedema” edema, and markedly elevated TSH with low T3/T4 consistent with primary hypothyroidism. The clinical picture (hypoventilation, hypothermia, mental status depression) plus the lab pattern point to myxedema coma rather than isolated environmental hypothermia or adrenal crisis. Immediate treatment (IV thyroid hormone, supportive care, and evaluation/treatment of precipitating causes) is required.
raw_c:
Yes — myxedema coma. 

Reason: this elderly patient has severe hypothyroidism with classic features (profound hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, altered mental status/coma, non‑pitting “myxedematous” edema, dry coarse skin) plus biochemical evidence of primary hypothyroidism (markedly elevated TSH with low T3/T4) and hyponatremia. These findings are diagnostic of myxedema coma (decompensated hypothyroidism).
raw_d:
No — the most likely diagnosis is myxedema coma (severe hypothyroidism), not tertiary hyperparathyroidism.

Reasoning: the patient has classic features of myxedema coma — profound hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, hypoventilation/altered mental status, nonpitting (myxedematous) edema, hyponatremia, sinus bradycardia on ECG, and markedly elevated TSH (110 µU/mL) with low T3/T4. Tertiary (or other) hyperparathyroidism would present with hypercalcemia and signs of chronic renal/bone disease and would not explain the very high TSH, hypothermia, bradycardia, hyponatremia, or myxedema.

question:
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for right upper quadrant abdominal pain that began 3 days ago. The pain is nonradiating and has no alleviating or exacerbating factors. He denies any nausea or vomiting. He immigrated from Mexico 6 months ago and currently works at a pet shop. He has been healthy except for 1 week of bloody diarrhea 5 months ago. He is 182 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 120 kg (264 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. His temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. He has tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.7 g/dL3
Leukocyte Count 14,000/mm
Segmented neutrophils 74%
Eosinophils 2%
Lymphocytes 17%
Monocytes 7%
Platelet count 140,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 139 mEq/L
Cl- 101 mEq/L
K+ 4.4 mEq/L
HCO3- 25 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 8 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL
AST 76 U/L
ALT 80 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase 103 U/L
Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a 4-cm round, hypoechoic lesion in the right lobe of the liver with low-level internal echoes. What is the most likely diagnosis?"
options: A. Amebiasis B. Hepatic hydatid cyst C. Liver hemangioma D. Pyogenic liver abscess E. Hepatocellular carcinoma
default:
Amebic (Entamoeba histolytica) liver abscess.  
Single right‑lobe hypoechoic lesion weeks–months after bloody diarrhea, fever and sterile “anchovy‑paste” abscesses on aspiration (no eosinophilia) are classic — treat with metronidazole followed by a luminal agent.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: amebic (Entamoeba histolytica) liver abscess.

Reasoning: The patient has fever, RUQ pain, leukocytosis and a solitary 4-cm hypoechoic hepatic lesion with low‑level internal echoes — classic for a liver abscess. His immigration from Mexico and a prior episode of bloody diarrhea 5 months ago strongly suggest prior intestinal entamoebiasis with hepatic spread. Hepatocellular carcinoma would be less likely here (usually in cirrhosis or chronic hepatitis, not typically febrile with acute leukocytosis and a preceding dysentery history).
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Amebic (Entamoeba histolytica) liver abscess.

Reasoning: A solitary right‑lobe hypoechoic liver lesion with low‑level internal echoes in a male immigrant with prior bloody diarrhea, fever, RUQ pain and mild transaminase elevation is classic for amebic liver abscess. Lack of eosinophilia argues against echinococcus, and the history/imaging fit amebiasis better than a pyogenic (bacterial) abscess. Confirm with serology and treat with metronidazole (with luminal therapy afterwards).
raw_c:
Amebic liver abscess from Entamoeba histolytica.

Reasoning: A single 4-cm right‑lobe hypoechoic lesion with fever, RUQ pain and neutrophilic leukocytosis in an immigrant from an endemic area plus a prior episode of bloody diarrhea fits amebic liver abscess (subacute presentation, often solitary in the right lobe). Lab pattern (mild transaminitis, normal bilirubin/alk phos) and low eosinophils favor amebiasis over hydatid disease (which often has eosinophilia and daughter cysts on imaging) and there is no biliary or intra‑abdominal source to suggest a pyogenic (polymicrobial) abscess. Diagnosis: serology and/or aspiration (anchovy‑paste fluid, sterile on culture); treat with metronidazole followed by a luminal agent (eg, paromomycin).
raw_d:
Amebic liver abscess (Entamoeba histolytica).

Reason: The combination of recent dysentery (bloody diarrhea months earlier), fever and RUQ pain, leukocytosis, and a solitary 4‑cm hypoechoic hepatic lesion with internal debris is classic for an amebic liver abscess in an immigrant from an endemic area. Hepatocellular carcinoma is unlikely here — it usually occurs in older patients with chronic liver disease/cirrhosis (and does not typically present with fever or a history of dysentery).

question: A 24-year-old man presents to the clinic with a one week history of pain in his left hand and stiffness in his right knee, with associated malaise and chills. He has no other past medical history, denies intravenous drug abuse, and has had no sick contacts. Vital signs are: T 38.5 C, BP 135/85, P 78, RR 16. Physical exam reveals swelling on the dorsum of the left hand and a warm erythematous right knee. The following non-painful lesions on the patients hands and ankles can be seen in Figure A. Laboratory analysis reveals a mild leukocytosis and negative blood cultures. What conditions is causing the presentation of this patient?
options: A. Acute meningococcemia B. Reiter's syndrome C. Acute bacterial endocarditis D. Disseminated gonococcal infection E. Sweet's syndrome
default: Disseminated gonococcal infection from Neisseria gonorrhoeae — i.e., gonococcal arthritis/tenosynovitis with the characteristic non‑tender pustular skin lesions on the hands/feet. Blood cultures are often negative.
raw_a:
Disseminated gonococcal infection (Neisseria gonorrhoeae).

Reason: The classic triad of DGI — migratory polyarthritis/tenosynovitis (dorsum of hand swelling), septic-appearing fever with chills, and painless pustular/vesiculopustular lesions on distal extremities — plus often negative blood cultures fits this presentation. Sweet’s syndrome typically causes tender, erythematous plaques (not the pustular lesions and tenosynovitis here) and is less consistent with the migratory arthritis/tenosynovitis pattern. Treat DGI promptly (e.g., ceftriaxone).
raw_b:
Conclusion: This is most consistent with disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Reasoning: The classic triad—tenosynovitis (dorsal hand swelling), migratory oligoarthralgias/arthritis (right knee), and pustular/vesiculopustular skin lesions on the extremities with fever—fits DGI. Blood cultures are often negative in DGI because N. gonorrhoeae is difficult to recover from blood. Infective endocarditis (Janeway lesions) is less likely here because IE more commonly gives persistently positive blood cultures and other stigmata (murmur, sustained bacteremia); Osler nodes are painful rather than the painless skin lesions described.
raw_c:
Yes — this is disseminated gonococcal infection (Neisseria gonorrhoeae). 

Reason: the presentation fits the classic arthritis‑dermatitis form of DGI — tenosynovitis (dorsal hand swelling), migratory arthralgias and a septic monoarthritis (warm, erythematous knee), plus multiple small pustular/nonpainful skin lesions. Blood cultures are often negative because N. gonorrhoeae is fastidious; diagnosis is made by NAAT/culture of mucosal or synovial sites and treated with ceftriaxone.
raw_d:
I'm still confident the presentation is disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI), not Sweet's syndrome.

Reasoning:
- The triad of fever, migratory arthralgias/tenosynovitis (dorsal hand swelling suggesting tenosynovitis) and non‑painful pustular skin lesions on the extremities is classic for DGI.  
- Blood cultures are often negative in DGI because Neisseria gonorrhoeae is fastidious; diagnosis is usually made by NAAT/culture from mucosal sites or synovial fluid.  
- Sweet's syndrome (acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis) typically causes tender, painful erythematous plaques rather than painless pustules, is more often associated with leukocytosis with marked neutrophilia and underlying malignancy/autoimmune disease, and does not classically produce tenosynovitis with migratory polyarthralgias.

If you want confirmation, obtain NAATs from urogenital/pharyngeal/rectal sites and synovial fluid analysis/culture.

question: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department 1 hour after the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and nausea. She has had one episode of nonbloody vomiting. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated, except for a blood pressure measurement of 150/90 mm Hg on her last prenatal visit. Her first child was delivered vaginally; her second child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. She appears anxious and pale. Her temperature is 36.1°C (96°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 92/65 mm Hg. Extremities are cool and clammy. Pelvic examination shows a rigid, tender uterus. The cervix is 30% effaced and 1 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. The fetal heart rate is 100/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Ruptured uterus B. Umbilical cord prolapse C. Ruptured vasa previa D. Chorioamnionitis E. Abruptio placentae F. Placenta accreta G. Placenta previa H. Uterine atony
default:
Placental abruption (abruptio placentae) — likely a concealed abruption. 

Rationale: sudden severe pain, a rigid/tender “board‑like” uterus, maternal shock with cool clammy extremities, and fetal distress at 32 weeks are classic for abruption; prior hypertension is a major risk factor. Uterine rupture is less likely (no advanced labor, minimal dilation/unchanged station, no palpable fetal parts).
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: placental abruption (concealed abruptio placentae).

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain with a rigid, tender (“board‑like”) uterus, maternal shock and fetal distress in a hypertensive patient are classic for abruption with concealed hemorrhage. Vasa previa typically causes painless vaginal bleeding after membrane rupture and acute fetal exsanguination, and uterine rigidity is not characteristic; uterine rupture is less likely here given a low transverse scar and lack of labor.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: placental abruption (abruptio placentae).

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain with a rigid, tender (hypertonic) uterus, maternal shock and fetal bradycardia at 32 weeks all point to a concealed retroplacental hemorrhage. Hypertension is a known risk factor for abruption, and external bleeding can be absent with concealed bleeding. Uterine rupture is less likely here (lower‑segment transverse scar, no loss of station or palpable fetal parts and no active labor described).
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: placental abruption (abruptio placentae).

Reasoning: Sudden severe abdominal pain with a rigid/tender (“boardlike”) uterus, maternal hypotension/tachycardia (shock), and fetal bradycardia at 32 weeks are classic for concealed abruption. Maternal HTN is a strong risk factor. Uterine rupture is less likely given no active labor, intact fetal station and minimal cervical dilation.
raw_d:
Most likely diagnosis: placental abruption (abruptio placentae).

Reasoning: sudden severe abdominal pain with a rigid, tender (hypertonic) uterus, maternal hypotension/tachycardia and pallor (shock), fetal bradycardia, and a history of hypertension are classic for abruptio placentae — bleeding can be concealed so vaginal blood may be absent. Ruptured vasa previa typically causes painless vaginal bleeding with immediate fetal exsanguination after membrane rupture and lacks uterine tenderness or maternal shock as the primary finding.

question: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of back pain for the past six months. The pain is worse with exercise and when reclining. He attends high school and is on the swim team. He also states that he lifts weights on a regular basis. He has not had any trauma to the back or any previous problems with his joints. He has no history of serious illness. His father has a disc herniation. Palpation of the spinous processes at the lumbosacral area shows that two adjacent vertebrae are displaced and are at different levels. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact throughout. When the patient is asked to walk, a waddling gait is noted. Passive raising of either the right or left leg causes pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Ankylosing spondylitis B. Spondylolisthesis C. Scheuermann's disease D. Facet joint syndrome E. Disc herniation F. Overuse injury
default: Isthmic spondylolisthesis — anterior slippage of one vertebra (classically L5 over S1) due to a pars interarticularis stress fracture. The step-off on palpation, pain worse with extension/exercise, gait changes, and radicular pain with straight‑leg raise in an adolescent athlete fit this diagnosis.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: isthmic spondylolisthesis (anterolisthesis from a pars interarticularis defect).

Reasoning: a palpable step-off of adjacent lumbar vertebrae indicates forward slippage, classic in adolescents who do repetitive hyperextension (swimming/weightlifting) causing a pars fracture → vertebral displacement (commonly L5 on S1). The positive straight‑leg raise with radiating leg pain and waddling gait reflect nerve-root/pelvic effects of the slippage. Facet joint syndrome would not produce a vertebral step‑off or this radicular picture.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: isthmic spondylolisthesis (anterior slippage of L5 on S1 due to a pars interarticularis defect).

Reasoning: the palpable "step‑off" at the lumbosacral junction, adolescent athlete with pain worse on extension/exercise, positive straight‑leg raise with ipsilateral radicular pain, and waddling gait are classic for pars defect progressing to spondylolisthesis. Disc herniation is less likely to produce a vertebral step‑off.
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: isthmic spondylolisthesis (anterior slippage of a lumbar vertebra, classically L5 over S1).

Reasoning: adolescent athlete with repetitive lumbar hyperextension (swimming/weightlifting) → pars interarticularis stress fracture with forward slippage; exam shows a palpable step-off (two adjacent spinous processes at different levels) and symptoms of nerve root irritation (radiating pain with straight‑leg raise). Pain worse with extension/reclining also fits spondylolisthesis rather than a typical disc herniation (which usually worsens with flexion and lacks a palpable step‑off).
raw_d:
Spondylolisthesis. 

The palpable step-off (two adjacent vertebrae displaced/at different levels) is the classic finding of vertebral slippage (usually L5 over S1) from pars interarticularis injury in adolescent athletes who do repetitive hyperextension. The pain worse with extension/reclining, waddling/antalgic gait, and radiating leg pain with a positive straight‑leg raise (nerve‑root irritation) further support slippage causing foraminal compression. Facet joint syndrome would cause localized paraspinal pain with motion but would not produce a palpable step‑off or the radicular SLR findings.

question: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department after numerous episodes of vomiting. The patient states that he thinks he ‘ate something weird’ and has been vomiting for the past 48 hours. He says that he came to the hospital because the last few times he "threw up blood". He is hypotensive with a blood pressure of 90/55 mm Hg and a pulse of 120/min. After opening an intravenous line, a physical examination is performed which is normal except for mild epigastric tenderness. An immediate endoscopy is performed and a tear involving the mucosa and submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction is visualized. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Boerhaave syndrome B. Gastric ulcer C. Esophageal varices D. Hiatal hernia E. Mallory-Weiss tear
default: Mallory-Weiss tear (Mallory-Weiss syndrome) — a mucosal/submucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal junction from severe retching/vomiting causing hematemesis.
raw_a:
The most likely diagnosis is a Mallory-Weiss tear.

Reason: Mallory-Weiss syndrome is a mucosal (and sometimes submucosal) laceration at the gastroesophageal junction caused by forceful retching and presents with hematemesis. Boerhaave syndrome is a transmural (full‑thickness) esophageal rupture with severe chest pain, mediastinitis, and pneumomediastinum — not just a mucosal/submucosal tear.
raw_b:
Diagnosis: Mallory–Weiss tear.

Reasoning: The patient has forceful vomiting followed by hematemesis and endoscopy shows a mucosal/submucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal junction — the classic presentation of a Mallory–Weiss tear. Boerhaave syndrome would be a full‑thickness (transmural) rupture with severe chest pain, pneumomediastinum and systemic sepsis, not an isolated mucosa/submucosa tear.
raw_c: Yes — Mallory-Weiss tear. The scenario of prolonged forceful vomiting followed by hematemesis and endoscopic visualization of a mucosal/submucosal tear at the gastroesophageal junction is classic. (By contrast Boerhaave syndrome is a transmural esophageal rupture with severe chest pain, mediastinitis and pneumomediastinum, not an isolated mucosal/submucosal laceration.)
raw_d:
Mallory‑Weiss tear. 

Reason: the endoscopy shows a mucosal/submucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal junction and the patient has hematemesis after severe retching—classic for Mallory‑Weiss. Boerhaave syndrome is a transmural (full‑thickness) esophageal rupture causing severe chest pain, mediastinitis and often free air/subcutaneous emphysema, not an isolated mucosal/submucosal tear.

question: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of difficulty swallowing of both solids and liquids for 1 month. During the past 5 months, he has also had increased weakness of his hands and legs. He sails regularly and is unable to hold the ropes as tightly as before. Ten years ago, he was involved in a motor vehicle collision. Examination shows atrophy of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. There is muscle stiffness in the left lower extremity. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right upper and lower extremities, 3+ in the left upper extremity, and 4+ in the left lower extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left foot. Sensation to light touch, pinprick, and vibration is intact. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options:
A. Myasthenia gravis B. Syringomyelia C. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis D. Inclusion-body myositis E. Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord F. Multifocal motor neuropathy G. Cervical spondylosis with myelopathy
"
default: The findings are most consistent with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) — combined upper- and lower-motor-neuron signs (tongue atrophy/bulbar dysfunction, asymmetric LMN weakness with atrophy and hyporeflexia on one side, UMN signs with hyperreflexia and Babinski on the other) with preserved sensation.
alternative: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Reason: He has progressive mixed upper- and lower-motor-neuron signs (LMN: tongue atrophy, focal weakness with hyporeflexia on the right; UMN: spasticity, hyperreflexia, extensor plantar on the left) with preserved sensation and bulbar involvement—classic for ALS. Subacute combined degeneration (B12 deficiency) would produce prominent dorsal-column sensory loss (vibration/proprioception) rather than the LMN bulbar findings seen here.
raw_b:
Diagnosis: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Reasoning: He has progressive, asymmetric mixed upper- and lower-motor–neuron findings (tongue atrophy and hyporeflexia on the right = LMN; hyperreflexia, spasticity and Babinski on the left = UMN) with bulbar involvement (dysphagia) and intact sensation. That combination—progressive motor weakness in multiple regions with preserved sensation—is classic for ALS. Other possibilities (myasthenia gravis, radiculopathy, stroke, peripheral neuropathy, MS) do not account for the simultaneous widespread UMN and LMN signs with bulbar involvement.
raw_c:
Yes — the most likely diagnosis is amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Reason: He has progressive bulbar involvement (dysphagia, tongue atrophy) plus a mixed pattern of lower motor neuron (atrophy, focal weakness, hyporeflexia on the right) and upper motor neuron signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia, extensor plantar on the left) in the same patient. Intact sensation and a motor-only process further support a motor neuron disease. Other possibilities (myasthenia gravis, peripheral neuropathy, stroke, MS) do not explain the concurrent, progressive UMN and LMN signs with preserved sensation.
raw_d:
The most likely diagnosis is amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Reasoning: This patient has progressive, asymmetric combinations of lower motor neuron (tongue atrophy, focal muscle weakness with decreased reflexes) and upper motor neuron signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia, extensor plantar) in the same regions, plus bulbar involvement causing dysphagia — a classic presentation of ALS. Sensation is intact, which argues strongly against subacute combined degeneration (B12 deficiency), which typically produces dorsal column loss (impaired vibration/position sense) and does not produce isolated bulbar LMN signs such as tongue atrophy.

question: A 65-year-old man presents to the ED a few hours after a minor motor vehicle accident with sudden onset of partial painless vision loss in his left eye. He is severely myopic, with a history of well controlled hypertension. Physical exam is normal, with no focal neurological deficits. He has no conjunctival injection, with no afferent pupillary defect. Prior to a visual acuity test, an ultrasound of the eye is performed as seen in Figure A. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Acute closed angle glaucoma B. Central artery occlusion C. Central vein occlusion D. Cortical blindness E. Retinal detachment
default: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment — ultrasound typically shows a mobile, undulating hyperechoic membrane tethered at the optic disc/ora serrata, and severe myopia plus acute painless “curtain” vision loss fits this diagnosis.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Reasoning: Sudden, painless unilateral vision loss in a severely myopic patient (a major risk factor) after minor trauma is classic for retinal detachment. Ocular US typically shows a thin, mobile, echogenic membrane floating off the posterior wall and often remaining tethered at the optic disc — findings consistent with RD. Cortical blindness is unlikely because it causes bilateral visual loss from occipital pathology and would not produce the characteristic ultrasound appearance.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: vitreous hemorrhage.

Reasoning: sudden painless visual loss after minor trauma in a highly myopic patient, with bedside ocular US showing diffuse, mobile low‑amplitude echoes within the vitreous cavity (rather than a taut, linear membrane tethered at the optic nerve head). Those findings are characteristic of blood in the vitreous; a retinal detachment would classically appear as a more continuous, anchored membrane that tracks to the optic disc.
raw_c:
Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Reasoning: sudden, painless “curtain” vision loss after minor trauma in a severely myopic patient strongly suggests retinal detachment. Ocular ultrasound classically shows a corrugated, echogenic membrane tethered at the optic disc that undulates with eye movement (distinct from diffuse low‑level echoes of vitreous hemorrhage or a freely mobile posterior vitreous detachment). Partial involvement can leave the afferent pupillary reflex intact.
raw_d:
Retinal detachment.

Reason: Acute, painless, unilateral vision loss in a highly myopic patient after trauma is classic for retinal detachment, and ocular ultrasound in that setting typically shows a mobile, undulating, V‑shaped membrane tethered at the optic nerve head. Cortical blindness is usually bilateral (occipital cortex) and would not produce an intraocular membrane on ultrasound. The absence of an afferent pupillary defect does not exclude a partial retinal detachment.

options: A. Septic shock B. Hypovolemic shock C. Anaphylactic shock D. Neurogenic shock E. Cardiogenic shock
default: Hypovolemic shock — low preload (low PCWP) causing low cardiac output with reflex vasoconstriction (high SVR). Findings (flat neck veins, delayed capillary refill, hypotension) support volume loss/hemorrhage.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: hypovolemic (hemorrhagic) shock.

Reasoning: low PCWP indicates low intravascular preload; low cardiac index reflects reduced stroke volume from low filling; high SVR is a compensatory vasoconstrictive response. Flat neck veins and prolonged capillary refill fit hypovolemia. Septic shock would show low SVR (vasodilation) and often a normal/high CO early, so it is unlikely here.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: hypovolemic shock.

Reasoning: the classic haemodynamic pattern for hypovolemia is low cardiac index (low CO from low preload), low PCWP (low left‑sided filling pressures) and a compensatory high systemic vascular resistance. The bedside findings (flat JVP, prolonged capillary refill) support poor intravascular volume and peripheral vasoconstriction. Other shock types don’t fit: cardiogenic shock would have an elevated PCWP, distributive (septic/anaphylactic) shock has low SVR, and obstructive causes (tamponade/tension/PE) usually produce raised JVP or other specific signs.
raw_c:
Hypovolemic shock.

Reason: low cardiac index and low PCWP indicate decreased preload/volume, while high systemic vascular resistance reflects compensatory vasoconstriction. Clinical signs (flat jugular veins, delayed capillary refill, hypotension) fit volume loss. Cardiogenic shock would have elevated PCWP; distributive (septic) shock has low SVR and warm extremities; obstructive shock usually has elevated JVP — so those are less likely.
raw_d:
Hypovolemic shock.

Reasoning: Low PCWP indicates low preload; low cardiac index follows from decreased intravascular volume; the high systemic vascular resistance reflects compensatory peripheral vasoconstriction. Septic (distributive) shock would typically have low SVR and often a normal/high CI (especially early) with warm, flushed skin and brisk capillary refill — findings inconsistent with this case.

question:
A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department with fever, chills, dyspnea, and a productive cough. His symptoms began suddenly 2 days ago. He was diagnosed with HIV 4 years ago and has been on triple antiretroviral therapy since then. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily. He is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 21.4 kg/m2. He lives in Illinois and works as a carpenter. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 105/74 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examinations reveals crackles over the right lower lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL
Leukocyte count 12,800/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 80%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 17%
Monocytes 2%
CD4+ T-lymphocytes 520/mm3(N ≥ 500)
Platelet count 258,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 137 mEq/L
Cl- 102 mEq/L
K+ 5.0 mEq/L
HCO3- 22 mEq/L
Glucose 92 mg/dL
An x-ray of the chest shows a right lower-lobe infiltrate of the lung. What is the most likely causal organism?"
options: A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis B. Haemophilus influenzae C. Histoplasma capsulatum D. Staphylococcus aureus E. Cryptococcus neoformans F. Mycobacterium avium complex G. Cytomegalovirus H. Legionella pneumophila I. Streptococcus pneumoniae J. Aspergillus fumigatus K. Pneumocystis jirovecii
default:
Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Rationale: sudden-onset fever/chills, productive cough, lobar (RLL) consolidation and neutrophilic leukocytosis are classic for typical community‑acquired pneumonia, most commonly S. pneumoniae (gram‑positive, lancet‑shaped diplococci). His CD4 count is normal, so opportunists are unlikely.
raw_a:
Most likely organism: Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Reasoning: Sudden onset high fever, rigors, productive cough and a lobar (right lower–lobe) infiltrate with neutrophilic leukocytosis are classic for pneumococcal (typical) community‑acquired pneumonia. His CD4 count is normal for HIV (≈520), so opportunists like Histoplasma or Pneumocystis (usually subacute/indolent or seen at low CD4 counts with diffuse interstitial infiltrates) are much less likely.
raw_b:
Haemophilus influenzae (nontypeable).

Reasoning: His HIV is well controlled (CD4 520) so he’s at risk for usual community‑acquired pathogens rather than opportunists. The acute, lobar pneumonia with neutrophilic leukocytosis is typical of a bacterial CAP, and chronic smoking is a strong risk factor for H. influenzae pneumonia. Other possibilities (Legionella, S. aureus, opportunists) are less likely given the presentation and lack of specific risk factors (no hyponatremia/GI symptoms for Legionella, no recent influenza/hospitalization for MRSA, and normal CD4 for opportunists).
raw_c:
Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Reason: Sudden onset high fever with rigors, productive cough, lobar (right lower‑lobe) consolidation and neutrophilic leukocytosis are classic for typical community‑acquired pneumonia from S. pneumoniae. His CD4 is >500 (opportunistic organisms unlikely). Atypical agents (Mycoplasma, Legionella) and Pneumocystis have different clinical and lab patterns (more subacute, interstitial x‑ray, hyponatremia for Legionella, PJP with low CD4), and although smokers can get H. influenzae, S. pneumoniae remains the most common cause.
raw_d:
Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Reason: The presentation — sudden onset high fever, productive cough, focal lobar (right lower lobe) infiltrate and neutrophilic leukocytosis — is classic for community-acquired lobar pneumonia from S. pneumoniae. His CD4 count is normal (≈520), so he is effectively immunocompetent; Histoplasma typically causes a more subacute/subclinical or disseminated illness (or hilar adenopathy/miliary pattern) related to heavy exposure (caves/bird or bat droppings) and is less likely to present as an acute lobar pneumonia with neutrophil predominance.

question: A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to sudden onset retrosternal chest pain. An ECG shows ST-segment elevation. A diagnosis of myocardial infarction is made and later confirmed by elevated levels of troponin I. The patient is sent to the cardiac catheter laboratory where she undergoes percutaneous catheterization. She has 2 occluded vessels in the heart and undergoes a percutaneous coronary intervention to place 2 stents in her coronary arteries. Blood flow is successfully restored in the affected arteries. The patient complains of flank pain on post-procedure evaluation a few hours later. A significant drop in hematocrit is observed, as well as a drop in her blood pressure to 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals extensive ecchymoses in the flanks and loin as seen in the provided image. What conditions is this patient most likely experiencing?
options: A. Complication from femoral artery access B. Fat embolism C. Patent ductus arteriosus D. Adrenal hemorrhage E. Ventricular septal defect
default: She most likely has a retroperitoneal hemorrhage from the femoral access site (producing flank ecchymoses = Grey‑Turner sign), with resulting acute blood loss/hypovolemic shock. Urgent imaging, reversal/stop of anticoagulation, transfusion and surgical/interventional control of the bleed are required.
raw_a:
Conclusion: She most likely has a retroperitoneal hemorrhage (access-site bleed) causing hypovolemic shock — the flank ecchymoses are Grey‑Turner sign. 

Reasoning: After PCI with anticoagulation and femoral access, sudden hypotension with a falling hematocrit and large flank/loin ecchymoses is classic for retroperitoneal bleeding. A post‑MI ventricular septal defect would cause acute heart failure and a new harsh holosystolic murmur, not external flank bruising or a hematocrit drop from hemorrhage. Immediate management: stop anticoagulants, volume/blood resuscitation, urgent CT abdomen/pelvis and vascular/IR/surgical control.
raw_b:
Conclusion: She most likely has a retroperitoneal hemorrhage (retroperitoneal hematoma) from vascular injury related to femoral artery access, producing hemorrhagic (hypovolemic) shock — classically producing flank/loin ecchymoses (Grey‑Turner sign).

Reasoning: After PCI via femoral access, sudden flank pain, a large drop in hematocrit, hypotension, and flank/loin ecchymosis are typical for bleeding into the retroperitoneal space (blood can track to the flanks producing Grey‑Turner sign and sometimes periumbilical Cullen sign). This is most commonly due to a high femoral arterial puncture (above the inguinal ligament) or access-related vessel injury, often exacerbated by procedural anticoagulation/antiplatelet therapy.

Immediate actions: resuscitate (IV fluids/blood), stop anticoagulants if possible, urgent CT abdomen/pelvis to confirm, and urgent vascular/IR consultation for angiographic localization and embolization (or surgery) as indicated.
raw_c:
She most likely has a retroperitoneal hemorrhage (femoral artery puncture/hematoma from the PCI) causing hemorrhagic (hypovolemic) shock. 

Reason: acute flank pain after femoral access, falling hematocrit and hypotension, and flank ecchymoses (Grey‑Turner sign) are classic for retroperitoneal bleeding from arterial injury after catheterization.
raw_d:
Conclusion: She most likely has a retroperitoneal hemorrhage from a femoral artery access complication causing hypovolemic shock.

Reasoning: Sudden post‑catheterization flank/loin ecchymoses (Grey‑Turner sign), acute drop in hematocrit and hypotension a few hours after PCI point to bleeding into the retroperitoneum (a known complication when the femoral puncture is high). A post‑MI ventricular septal defect would present with a new harsh systolic murmur and signs of acute heart failure/cardiogenic shock, not flank ecchymosis or rapid Hct loss.

question: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening shortness of breath for 3 days. He has had fever and malaise for the past 5 days. He had a sore throat 3 weeks ago that resolved without treatment. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 98/min and blood pressure is 84/62 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Examination shows jugular venous distension and bilateral ankle edema. There are erythematous, ring-shaped macules and patches over his trunk that are well-demarcated. Auscultation of the chest shows crackles at the lung bases bilaterally. An S3 is heard on cardiac auscultation. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.2 g/dL, leukocyte count is 13,600/mm3, and platelet count is 280,000/mm3. A urinalysis is normal. An x-ray of the chest shows cardiac silhouette enlargement with prominent vascular markings in both the lung fields. What is the most likely etiology of this patient's symptoms?
options: A. Acute rheumatic fever B. Viral myocarditis C. Systemic lupus erythematosus D. Infection with Borrelia burgdorferi E. Kawasaki disease
default: An immune-mediated (type II hypersensitivity) reaction after group A streptococcal pharyngitis — anti–streptococcal antibodies (eg, to M protein) cross‑react with cardiac tissue (rheumatic myocarditis/pancarditis causing heart failure).
raw_a:
Most likely etiology: immune-mediated poststreptococcal (rheumatic) carditis from group A Streptococcus infection (molecular mimicry from anti–M protein antibodies).

Reasoning: The history of untreated sore throat 2–3 weeks earlier, fever, annular trunk rash consistent with erythema marginatum, and signs of congestive heart failure with an S3, JVD, edema, and cardiomegaly are classic for acute rheumatic fever causing myocarditis/pancarditis. The pathology is a type II hypersensitivity (antibodies against streptococcal M protein cross‑react with cardiac tissue).
raw_b:
Conclusion: Acute viral myocarditis (most likely enterovirus/Coxsackie B) causing dilated cardiomyopathy and acute heart failure.

Reasoning: The child has a recent febrile prodrome, new-onset CHF with S3, cardiomegaly and pulmonary edema on CXR, hypotension and JVD—all typical of fulminant myocarditis. The rash and systemic symptoms fit a viral illness. Acute rheumatic fever is less likely because RF usually produces migratory arthritis, valvulitis (murmur) and other Jones criteria findings (subcutaneous nodules, chorea) rather than the rapid cardiogenic shock/dilated cardiomyopathy picture seen here; rheumatic carditis severe enough to cause this presentation is uncommon. Viral myocarditis (eg, Coxsackie B) best explains the acute course and hemodynamic instability.
raw_c:
The most likely etiology is acute rheumatic fever causing poststreptococcal pancarditis (immune‑mediated valve/myocardial inflammation).

Reasoning: he had an untreated sore throat ~3 weeks ago (typical latency for ARF), now has fever, heart failure with cardiomegaly/S3/JVD/crackles, and erythema marginatum (ring‑shaped, well‑demarcated trunk lesions) — all consistent with Jones criteria for rheumatic fever. Viral myocarditis could present with heart failure but would not explain the characteristic erythematous ring lesions or the classic timing after streptococcal pharyngitis.
raw_d:
Most likely acute rheumatic fever due to a post–group A streptococcal immune reaction (molecular mimicry causing carditis).

Reasoning: the presentation is 2–3 weeks after an untreated sore throat (classic latency for rheumatic fever), with ring‑shaped, well‑demarcated erythematous lesions consistent with erythema marginatum and signs of cardiac failure (S3, cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, JVD). Rheumatic carditis is immune‑mediated cross‑reactivity between anti‑streptococcal antibodies (eg, to M protein) and cardiac tissue. Lyme disease typically produces a solitary erythema migrans at a tick bite site and more commonly conduction blocks rather than the diffuse myocarditis/heart‑failure picture seen here.

question: An 18-year-old male is brought in by fire rescue. The patient was an unrestrained passenger in a motor vehicle crash and was ejected from the vehicle after collision. Upon arrival to the trauma bay, the patient has a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) of 6. He is rapidly intubated, and vitals are a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse of 130 bpm, and blood pressure of 83/64 mmHg. He is noted to have multiple ecchymoses over his body, as well as petechiae and purpura. He has a laceration over his clavicle that continues to bleed despite a pressure bandage. Radiographs of his lower extremity show multiple long bone fractures. Two large bore IV lines are placed, and the patient oozes from around the sites of venepuncture. Labs are notable for a WBC of 20,000/mm^3, Hb of 10.1g/dL, platelets of 48,000/mm^3, and prolongation of the PT and aPTT. This patient's presentation can best be explained by which of the following diagnoses?
options: A. Fat embolization B. Air embolization C. Tension pneumothorax D. Disseminated intravascular coagulation E. Coagulopathy of trauma
default: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) — a consumptive coagulopathy from massive tissue injury. The combination of bleeding from puncture sites, petechiae/purpura, thrombocytopenia, prolonged PT/aPTT, and ongoing oozing after trauma/long‑bone fractures is classic for DIC.
raw_a:
The best diagnosis is disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), not air embolism.

Reasoning: Massive trauma/long‑bone fractures and shock can trigger DIC — the patient has diffuse bleeding/oozing from puncture sites, petechiae/purpura, severe thrombocytopenia, and prolonged PT/aPTT consistent with a consumption coagulopathy. Air embolism causes abrupt cardiopulmonary collapse and neurologic signs but would not explain the global coagulopathy and oozing from IV sites.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Acute disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) from severe trauma.

Reasoning: The patient has a classic consumptive coagulopathy picture — bleeding from wounds and IV sites, ecchymoses/petechiae/purpura, marked thrombocytopenia, and prolonged PT/aPTT — in the setting of major tissue injury and multiple long‑bone fractures (release of tissue factor). Fat embolism syndrome can cause petechiae and neuro changes but usually occurs 24–72 hours after injury and does not typically produce this coagulation-profile; TTP/HIT would not produce prolonged PT/aPTT in this acute trauma context.
raw_c:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Reason: Severe trauma with multiple long-bone fractures releases tissue factor → widespread coagulation with consumption of platelets and clotting factors, producing bleeding from wounds/IV sites, petechiae/purpura, thrombocytopenia (platelets 48k) and prolonged PT/aPTT. Alternative causes (TTP, ITP, hemophilia) would not produce the combination of consumptive coagulopathy with prolonged PT/aPTT seen here.
raw_d:
No — the findings are most consistent with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Reasoning:
- The patient has active bleeding from wounds, oozing at IV sites, widespread petechiae/purpura, thrombocytopenia (platelets 48k), and prolonged PT/aPTT — a classic consumptive coagulopathy pattern of DIC triggered by severe trauma and multiple long-bone fractures (tissue factor release).
- Air embolism typically causes sudden cardiopulmonary collapse, hypoxia, and maybe a "mill wheel" murmur, but it does not produce a consumptive coagulopathy with prolonged PT/aPTT and diffuse bleeding.
- (For completeness: fat embolism from long-bone fractures can cause petechiae and neurologic/respiratory signs, but it usually presents 24–72 hours later and does not explain the marked coagulopathy and oozing seen here.)

question: An 81-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a left-sided paralysis for the past 2 hours. Her husband says her symptoms began suddenly, and she is also unable to speak. Her pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), and blood pressure is 150/98 mm Hg. An ECG is obtained and is shown below. What is the most probable cause of the patient's paralysis?
options: A. Cardioembolic stroke B. Cocaine toxicity C. Conversion disorder D. Hemorrhagic disorder E. Rupture of berry aneurysm
default: A cardioembolic ischemic stroke — thrombus formed in the left atrium/left atrial appendage from atrial fibrillation that embolized and acutely occluded a middle cerebral artery. This causes sudden focal deficits (hemiparesis and aphasia).
raw_a:
Most probable cause: an acute cardioembolic ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation (embolus from the left atrium).

Reasoning: the neurologic deficits began suddenly (classic for embolic ischemia), and the ECG shows atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular rhythm with absent organized P waves) — a common source of cardiac thrombi that embolize to cerebral arteries. Hemorrhagic stroke is less likely here (would more often present with severe headache, decreased consciousness, and is not specifically linked to AF on ECG).
raw_b:
Most probable cause: a cardioembolic ischemic stroke from atrial fibrillation (an embolus from the heart occluding a cerebral artery).

Reasoning: the deficits began suddenly (classic for embolic stroke), the ECG shows atrial fibrillation (a common source of left‑atrial thrombi that embolize), and the patient has acute cortical signs (speech disturbance consistent with an MCA territory infarct). Atherosclerotic carotid disease and lacunar infarcts are less likely given the abrupt onset and the ECG evidence of a cardiac embolic source.
raw_c:
Most likely an embolic ischemic stroke from atrial fibrillation — a thrombus formed in the left atrium/left atrial appendage that embolized to a cerebral artery (cardioembolic stroke).

Reasoning: the deficit began suddenly (characteristic of embolic stroke), and the ECG shows atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular rhythm without P waves), which causes blood stasis in the left atrium and thrombus formation with high risk of cerebral embolization. (Localization of speech loss vs sided weakness can vary with handedness or exact arterial branch involved.)
raw_d:
Most probable cause: Cardioembolic ischemic stroke from atrial fibrillation (embolus to the dominant MCA).

Reasoning: The deficits began suddenly and were maximal at onset (classic for embolic ischemia), with aphasia and contralateral hemiparesis localizing to the dominant MCA territory. The ECG demonstrates atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular rhythm without P waves), a common source of cardiac emboli. Hemorrhagic stroke is less likely given the presentation (no severe headache, vomiting, or depressed consciousness) and the presence of AF pointing to an embolic cause — head CT would be needed to exclude hemorrhage before thrombolysis.

question: A 31-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fever and increasing confusion for the past day. He has bipolar disorder with psychotic features and hypothyroidism. Current medications are lithium, haloperidol, and levothyroxine. He drinks one beer with dinner every night. His speech is confused and he is oriented to person only. His temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 124/min, and blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg. He appears acutely ill. Examination shows diaphoresis and muscle rigidity. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. There is minor rigidity of the neck with full range of motion. His lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender. His leukocyte count is 15,100/mm3 and serum creatine kinase activity is 1100 U/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Malignant hyperthermia B. Delirium tremens C. Serotonin syndrome D. Herpes simplex encephalitis E. Bacterial meningitis F. Systemic bacterial infection G. Lithium toxicity H. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
default: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) — the classic picture of antipsychotic-associated high fever, "lead‑pipe" rigidity, autonomic instability, mental status change, leukocytosis and markedly elevated CK with hyporeflexia. (Differs from serotonin syndrome, which causes hyperreflexia and clonus.)
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS).

Reasoning: High fever, severe confusion, autonomic instability, "lead‑pipe" muscle rigidity with decreased deep tendon reflexes, markedly elevated CK, and leukocytosis in a patient taking haloperidol strongly point to NMS. Lack of marked nuchal rigidity and preserved neck range of motion argue against bacterial meningitis; additionally meningitis usually causes marked meningeal signs rather than generalized rigidity and an elevated CK.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS).

Reasoning: He’s on haloperidol and has the classic tetrad for NMS — severe hyperthermia, altered mental status, “lead‑pipe” muscle rigidity with decreased/normal deep‑tendon reflexes, and autonomic instability (tachycardia, HTN, diaphoresis) — plus leukocytosis and markedly elevated CK from muscle breakdown. Serotonin syndrome would show hyperreflexia and clonus (not present here), malignant hyperthermia requires recent anesthesia, and thyroid storm or lithium toxicity do not typically produce this rigidity/CK picture.
raw_c:
Yes — neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). 

He’s on haloperidol and has the classic tetrad: recent antipsychotic exposure, high fever, severe generalized rigidity with autonomic instability (tachycardia, labile BP, diaphoresis) and altered mental status, plus marked CK elevation and leukocytosis. Decreased/normal reflexes and absence of clonus distinguish NMS from serotonin syndrome; malignant hyperthermia requires anesthetic exposure.
raw_d:
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS).

He’s on haloperidol and presents with high fever, marked autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis), severe generalized muscle rigidity with markedly elevated CK and leukocytosis — a classic NMS picture. The diminished reflexes also favor NMS (contrast with serotonin syndrome, which has hyperreflexia/clonus). Bacterial meningitis would typically cause pronounced nuchal rigidity/meningismus, severe headache, photophobia, and CSF abnormalities; here neck rigidity is minor with full range of motion and there are no focal meningeal signs to suggest meningitis.

question: A 63-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of an enlarging red area on his forehead that recently opened up and is now ulcerating. The patient reports that he first noticed the lesion 6 months ago, when he thought it was a pimple. He denies any antecedent trauma to the area. Of note, the patient works as a parking lot attendant and has a history of 2 basal cell carcinomas on his neck that were previously excised. On exam, his temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 12/min. On the forehead, there is an erythematous patch approximately 3 centimeters at greatest diameter with surrounding scale and central ulceration of 0.5 cm. The patient is referred to a dermatologist and the lesion is excised. The histopathological slide is shown in Figure A. What is most associated with this type of lesion?
options: A. May spread to nodes but rarely with distant metastases B. Most common skin cancer C. Palisading nuclei on histology D. Pearly appearance with telangiectasias E. Precursor to malignancy
solution_text: May spread to nodes but rarely with distant metastases
default: The lesion is a cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma — classically associated with chronic sun (UV) damage/actinic (solar) keratoses with UV‑induced p53 mutations, and it has a higher risk of metastasis to regional lymph nodes.
alternative: May spread to nodes but rarely with distant metastases
raw_a: Correct — this is most consistent with cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma, which commonly invades locally and can spread to regional (cutaneous) lymph nodes but only uncommonly gives distant metastases. Reason: sun-exposed site with ulceration and typical histology (keratin pearls/intercellular bridges) links to actinic damage/actinic keratoses → SCC, which has higher nodal than hematogenous metastatic risk.
raw_b:
Conclusion: This is cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (not basal cell carcinoma) — most characteristically associated with keratin pearls and intercellular bridges and with chronic UV/actinic damage (actinic keratoses) and a risk of regional lymph node metastasis.

Reasoning: An enlarging scaly, ulcerating lesion on a sun‑exposed forehead in an older patient fits SCC; histology of SCC shows keratinization (keratin pearls) and desmosomal intercellular bridges rather than the palisading nuclei seen in basal cell carcinoma.
raw_c:
Conclusion: This is squamous cell carcinoma — most associated with keratin pearls on histology and with antecedent actinic keratoses from chronic sun (UV) exposure. 

Reasoning: The lesion is a scaly, enlarging ulcerating plaque on sun‑exposed forehead in an older, outdoor worker — classic for SCC. Histology of SCC shows keratinization (keratin pearls) and intercellular bridges; SCC is linked to actinic damage, HPV (mucosal sites), arsenic exposure, and has a higher metastatic risk than BCC.
raw_d:
Conclusion: This is squamous cell carcinoma — it commonly spreads to regional lymph nodes but rarely gives distant metastases.

Reasoning: The clinical picture (ulcerating, enlarging lesion on sun‑exposed forehead in an older man with chronic sun exposure) plus histology consistent with squamous differentiation (keratin pearls/intercellular bridges) fits SCC. Palisading nuclei describe basal cell carcinoma, which is different and rarely metastasizes at all.

question: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of multiple episodes of nausea and vomiting that last about 2 hours. During this period, she has had 6–8 episodes of bilious vomiting and abdominal pain. The vomiting was preceded by fatigue. The girl feels well between these episodes. She has missed several days of school and has been hospitalized 2 times during the past 6 months for dehydration due to similar episodes of vomiting and nausea. The patient has lived with her mother since her parents divorced 8 months ago. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 60th percentile for height and 30th percentile for weight. She appears emaciated. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.8°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 82/52 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination shows a soft abdomen with mild diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Cyclic vomiting syndrome B. Volvulus C. Gastroenteritis D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis E. Gastroesophageal reflux disease F. Acute intermittent porphyria
default: Most likely cyclic vomiting syndrome. The child has recurrent, stereotyped episodes of intense vomiting with a prodrome (fatigue), symptom-free intervals, normal exam between episodes, and stressors — classic for CVS rather than continuous obstruction, infection, or metabolic disease.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS).

Reasoning: The child has recurrent, stereotyped episodes of intense vomiting with a prodrome (fatigue), symptom-free intervals between episodes, normal exam between episodes, and multiple prior hospitalizations — a pattern classic for CVS. Acute gastroenteritis would be a single, continuous illness (often with fever/diarrhea) rather than repeated, identical episodes over months.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS).

Reasoning: The child has recurrent, stereotyped episodes of intense vomiting lasting hours with complete symptom-free intervals, a prodrome (fatigue), and multiple prior hospitalizations for dehydration — a classic pattern for CVS in young children. Examination is normal between attacks and there are no signs of an acute surgical abdomen or systemic infection. Other causes (acute gastroenteritis, obstruction, metabolic/porphyric disease) would usually show persistent abnormal findings or additional systemic/neurologic signs; factitious illness (Munchausen by proxy) should be considered only if the history is inconsistent or objective testing doesn’t support CVS. Workup should still exclude organic causes (basic labs, electrolytes, abdominal imaging as indicated) and then manage acutely with fluids/antiemetics and refer to pediatric gastroenterology for prevention and supportive care.
raw_c:
Most likely diagnosis: cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS).

Reasoning: She has recurrent, stereotyped episodes of intense vomiting and abdominal pain with completely well intervals, episodes precipitated by fatigue/stress (parents’ divorce), multiple prior hospitalizations for dehydration, normal exam between episodes, and no peritoneal signs to suggest an acute surgical abdomen. These features are classic for CVS (part of the migraine spectrum in children). 

Why other diagnoses are less likely: intermittent intestinal obstruction/volvulus can cause bilious vomiting but usually produces more persistent/severe abdominal signs and progressive symptoms and is a surgical emergency. Infectious gastroenteritis would not produce recurrent, identical symptom-free intervals over months. Metabolic/renal causes would have other systemic findings.

Clinical note: Because bilious vomiting can signal obstruction, persistent bilious vomiting, peritoneal signs, or worsening exam would warrant urgent imaging (abdominal films/upper GI series) to exclude malrotation or obstruction. Otherwise refer to pediatrics/pediatric GI for evaluation and prophylactic/abortive therapy for CVS.
raw_d:
Cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS) is still the most likely diagnosis.

Reasoning: This child has recurrent, stereotyped episodes of intense vomiting with a prodrome (fatigue), complete symptom-free intervals between episodes, and multiple hospitalizations over months — which fits the Rome IV/clinical criteria for CVS. Gastroenteritis is usually a single acute illness with fever and diarrhea, not recurrent discrete episodes over months with normal intervals. That said, bilious vomiting is a red flag for obstruction and would warrant prompt imaging to exclude surgical causes, but overall the pattern here favors CVS over gastroenteritis.

question: A 29-year-old African-American woman, gravida 4, para 0, comes to the physician for evaluation of recurrent abortions. Each pregnancy resulted in spontaneous abortion in the second trimester. The patient has a history of joint pain, chronic migraines, and recurrent poorly defined, macular skin rashes. She also reports episodes in which her fingers become pale and cold, and then redden. She is sexually active with her husband and does not use contraceptives. The patient works as a landscape architect. Her mother has a history of endometriosis. The patient takes a daily prenatal multivitamin and occasionally sumatriptan. She appears tired. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Examination of the hands shows two ulcerations on the tip of the right index finger and multiple tiny hemorrhages under the nails. There is a purple reticular rash on both calves. What is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
options: A. Test for cryoglobulins B. Complete blood count C. Hysteroscopy D. Factor V Leiden functional testing E. Test for anticardiolipin antibodies F. Blood smear for sickle cells
default: Findings are most consistent with antiphospholipid syndrome. Confirm by testing for antiphospholipid antibodies — eg, a positive lupus anticoagulant (dilute Russell viper venom test) and/or anticardiolipin/anti–β2‑glycoprotein I antibodies on ≥2 occasions ≥12 weeks apart.
raw_a:
Conclusion: Yes — demonstration of antiphospholipid antibodies, most commonly anticardiolipin IgG/IgM (or lupus anticoagulant or anti–β2‑glycoprotein I), confirmed on repeat testing ≥12 weeks apart, would confirm the diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome.

Reasoning: Her recurrent mid‑trimester fetal losses, livedo reticularis, digital ischemic ulcers/splinter hemorrhages, Raynaud phenomena and migrainous/joint symptoms are classic for APS (thrombotic placental disease). Anticardiolipin antibodies (or a positive lupus anticoagulant that prolongs PTT and fails to correct on mixing) are diagnostic when persistently positive.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Test for antiphospholipid antibodies (eg, lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin and anti–β2‑glycoprotein I antibodies) — positive tests on two occasions ≥12 weeks apart confirm antiphospholipid syndrome.

Reasoning: Recurrent mid‑trimester pregnancy loss, livedo reticularis, digital ischemic ulcers/splinter hemorrhages and systemic symptoms (arthralgias, migraines) point to APS (hypercoagulable state causing arterial/venous thrombosis and pregnancy morbidity). Factor V Leiden is less consistent with the livedo/ischemia picture and pregnancy timing; it is diagnosed by APC‑resistance or DNA testing, but APS antibody testing is the appropriate confirmatory workup here.
raw_c:
Positive antiphospholipid antibodies — eg, a positive lupus anticoagulant or anticardiolipin/anti–β2‑glycoprotein I antibody test (confirmed on repeat testing ≥12 weeks later).

Reason: recurrent mid‑trimester pregnancy loss, livedo reticularis, digital ischemia/ulceration, migraines and joint symptoms are classic for antiphospholipid syndrome, which is diagnosed by antiphospholipid antibody testing (eg, dRVVT for lupus anticoagulant or anticardiolipin/anti‑β2GPI assays).
raw_d:
Antiphospholipid antibody testing — for example, anticardiolipin antibodies (and/or lupus anticoagulant or anti–β2‑glycoprotein I); persistent positivity (on 2 occasions ≥12 weeks apart) confirms antiphospholipid syndrome.

Reasoning: her recurrent mid‑trimester fetal losses, livedo reticularis, digital ischemic ulcers/splinter hemorrhages, Raynaud and migrainelike symptoms point to antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (thrombophilia from antiphospholipid antibodies), not Factor V Leiden.

question: A 21-year-old female was brought to the emergency room after losing large amounts of blood from slicing her wrists longitudinally. A few days later, she was interviewed by the psychiatrist and discussed with him why she had tried to kill herself. "My evil boyfriend of 2 months left me because I never let him leave my side for fear that he would cheat on me and leave me...now I feel so empty without him." What personality disorders does this female most likely have?
options: A. Histrionic B. Dependent C. Avoidant D. Borderline E. Paranoid
default: Borderline personality disorder — features shown: frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment, unstable/intense relationships, recurrent suicidal/self‑mutilating behavior, and chronic feelings of emptiness.
raw_a:
Borderline personality disorder.

Reason: She shows classic BPD features—intense fear of abandonment, frantic efforts to avoid real/imagined separation, recurrent self‑harm/parasuicidal behavior (wrist cutting), unstable/impulsive relationships, and feelings of emptiness. Histrionic (attention‑seeking, theatrical) or dependent (clinginess without typical suicidal/self‑mutilating behavior) fit less well.
raw_b:
Most likely Borderline Personality Disorder (possibly with dependent traits).

Reasoning: her behavior matches core BPD criteria — frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment (“never let him leave my side”), self‑injury/suicidal behavior (slicing wrists), and a chronic feeling of emptiness after the breakup. Dependent PD can explain clinginess but typically lacks the self‑harm, emptiness, and the identity/affect instability characteristic of BPD; histrionic or avoidant PDs fit less well.
raw_c:
Most likely Borderline Personality Disorder.

Reasoning: she shows classic BPD features — frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment, unstable and intense interpersonal relationships, recurrent suicidal behavior/self‑mutilation, and feelings of emptiness/identity disturbance. These symptoms fit DSM‑5 BPD better than dependent, histrionic, or other PDs (dependent patients are clinging/submissive but typically lack recurrent self‑harm and the marked identity/emptiness seen here).
raw_d:
Borderline personality disorder.

Her presentation—recurrent suicidal/self‑harm behavior, frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment, an unstable/intense (short‑lived) relationship pattern and chronic feelings of emptiness—matches core DSM criteria for borderline PD. Histrionic PD is characterized mainly by attention‑seeking, theatricality and shallow emotions, and does not typically feature the marked fear of abandonment, recurrent self‑injury, or identity/relationship instability shown here (though comorbidity can occur).

question: A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a rear-end collision, in which she was the restrained driver of the back car. On arrival, she is alert and active. She reports pain in both knees and severe pain over the right groin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 116/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 132/79 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness over both knee caps. The right groin is tender to palpation. The right leg is slightly shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options:
A. Femoral neck fracture B. Anterior hip dislocation C. Femoral shaft fracture D. Posterior hip dislocation E. Pelvic fracture
"
default: Posterior dislocation of the right hip (femoral head displaced posteriorly). The dashboard mechanism in a restrained driver with the limb flexed produces the classic short, flexed, adducted, internally rotated deformity; requires urgent reduction.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: Posterior dislocation of the right hip.

Reasoning: The classic dashboard mechanism (knee impact in a restrained driver) produces posterior hip dislocation. The affected limb is typically shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated — exactly the described position. A femoral shaft fracture would more often produce deformity and not the characteristic flexed/adducted/internal rotation posture; femoral neck fractures classically cause external rotation. Posterior hip dislocation requires urgent reduction (and assessment for sciatic nerve injury and vascular/AVN risk).
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: posterior dislocation of the right hip.

Reasoning: the mechanism (rear‑end/dashboard impact), plus the classic limb posture—shortened, flexed, adducted and internally rotated—are diagnostic for posterior femoral head dislocation. This is an orthopedic emergency (urgent reduction to reduce risk of sciatic nerve injury and avascular necrosis).
raw_c:
Yes — posterior (posterolateral) dislocation of the hip. 

Reason: a dashboard-type rear‑end collision driving the flexed femur posteriorly is classic for posterior hip dislocation, and the affected limb classically appears shortened, flexed, adducted and internally rotated. By contrast, anterior hip dislocation (or femoral neck fracture) produces abduction/external rotation. This is an orthopedic emergency (urgent reduction and neurovascular assessment, esp. sciatic nerve).
raw_d:
Posterior dislocation of the right hip.

Reasoning: The mechanism (dashboard-type force in a rear-end collision) plus the classic limb posture — shortened, flexed, adducted, and internally rotated — strongly indicates a posterior femoral head dislocation. A femoral shaft fracture would more commonly produce frank deformity/angulation and often external rotation of the limb rather than the described internal rotation. Emergency reduction is required for a hip dislocation to reduce the risk of avascular necrosis.

question: A 65-year-old woman was referred to a specialist for dysphagia and weight loss. She has a history of difficulty swallowing solid foods, which has become worse over the past year. She has unintentionally lost 2.3 kg (5 lb). A previous gastroscopy showed mild gastritis with a positive culture for Helicobacter pylori. A course of triple antibiotic therapy and omeprazole was prescribed. Follow-up endoscopy appeared normal with no H. pylori noted on biopsy. Her heartburn improved but the dysphagia persisted. She had a myocardial infarction four years ago, complicated by acute mitral regurgitation. Physical examination revealed a thin woman with normal vital signs. Auscultation of the heart reveals a 3/6 blowing systolic murmur at the apex radiating to the axilla. Breath sounds are reduced at the base of the right lung. The abdomen is mildly distended but not tender. The liver and spleen are not enlarged. Electrocardiogram shows sinus rhythm with a non-specific intraventricular block. Chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with mild pleural effusion. What is the most probable cause of dysphagia?
options: A. Thoracic aortic aneurysm B. Achalasia C. Left atrium enlargement D. Diffuse esophageal spasm E. Benign stricture
default: Extrinsic esophageal compression from an enlarged left atrium due to chronic mitral regurgitation/cardiomegaly (left atrial enlargement compressing the esophagus), causing progressive solid-food dysphagia.
raw_a:
Most likely cause: extrinsic compression of the esophagus by an enlarged left atrium from chronic mitral valve disease (post‑MI mitral regurgitation).

Reasoning: progressive dysphagia to solids with a normal endoscopy points to extrinsic compression. Exam and CXR show cardiomegaly and features of mitral regurgitation (apical systolic murmur radiating to the axilla), so left atrial enlargement from chronic MR is the best explanation for esophageal compression and dysphagia.
raw_b:
Conclusion: Her dysphagia is most likely from extrinsic esophageal compression by an enlarged left atrium due to chronic mitral regurgitation/cardiomegaly.

Reasoning: She has a long‑standing MR (apical blowing systolic murmur radiating to the axilla), cardiomegaly and mild pleural effusion on CXR, and a normal upper endoscopy (making intrinsic mucosal lesions such as carcinoma or peptic stricture less likely). Left atrial enlargement from chronic mitral valve disease commonly produces progressive dysphagia from external compression of the posterior esophagus. To confirm, obtain transthoracic echo (to document LA size) and a barium swallow or chest CT to demonstrate the extrinsic impression.
raw_c:
Most probable cause: external compression of the esophagus by an enlarged left atrium (cardiogenic dysphagia) secondary to chronic mitral valve disease/mitral regurgitation.

Reasoning: her dysphagia is progressive for solids (suggesting extrinsic or mechanical obstruction), but follow-up upper endoscopy was normal (argues against an intraluminal tumor). Exam and CXR show cardiomegaly and a holosystolic apical murmur radiating to the axilla (mitral regurgitation), and prior MI with MR can lead to left‑atrial enlargement that compresses the posteriorly‑laid esophagus. To confirm, get echocardiography and/or a barium swallow or chest CT to demonstrate LA enlargement and extrinsic compression.
raw_d:
Left atrial enlargement is the most likely cause.

She has a history of acute mitral regurgitation after her MI and now a classic apical holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla, cardiomegaly on chest x‑ray and signs of congestive change—features consistent with chronic MR leading to left atrial dilatation. The enlarged left atrium lies immediately posterior to the esophagus and commonly produces progressive dysphagia to solids by extrinsic compression. A thoracic aortic aneurysm is possible but would more likely show mediastinal widening or a prominent aortic knob and different risk/clinical clues that are not present here.

question: A 63-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of progressive blurring and darkening of her vision in the right eye. Upon waking up in the morning, she suddenly started seeing multiple dark streaks. She has migraines and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed at her last health maintenance examination 20 years ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Her only medication is sumatriptan. Her vitals are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/40 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. The fundus is obscured and difficult to visualize on fundoscopic examination of the right eye. The red reflex is diminished on the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Central retinal vein occlusion B. Central retinal artery occlusion C. Cataract D. Retinal detachment E. Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy F. Migraine aura G. Vitreous hemorrhage
default:
Most likely diagnosis: vitreous hemorrhage — most likely from proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Rationale: sudden onset of floaters/dark streaks, markedly reduced red reflex and an obscured fundus (blood in the vitreous blocks visualization) in a patient with long-standing diabetes strongly points to vitreous hemorrhage from fragile neovascular vessels.
raw_a:
Most likely diagnosis: vitreous hemorrhage (likely from proliferative diabetic retinopathy).

Reasoning: sudden onset of multiple dark streaks/floaters and a “curtain-like” obscuration of vision, long history of diabetes (risk for neovascularization), an obscured fundus and a diminished red reflex all point to blood in the vitreous blocking visualization. Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy would typically show optic disc edema/afferent pupillary defect and not a diffusely obscured fundus or markedly reduced red reflex. Urgent ophthalmology evaluation (B‑scan ultrasound if the fundus cannot be seen) is indicated.
raw_b:
Most likely diagnosis: vitreous hemorrhage.

Reasoning: sudden onset of multiple dark floaters and progressive darkening of vision, a diminished red reflex, and an obscured fundus are classic for blood in the vitreous. Her 20-year history of diabetes makes proliferative diabetic retinopathy with neovascular bleeding the most likely source. Other alternatives are less likely: retinal detachment typically presents with a “curtain” and visible retinal elevation/traction (fundus often still partially visible) and posterior vitreous detachment causes floaters but usually preserves the red reflex and allows fundus visualization; central retinal artery/vein occlusions show characteristic fundus findings rather than an obscured view.
raw_c:
Most likely vitreous hemorrhage.

Reasoning: sudden onset of new floaters/dark streaks with acute visual blurring, an obscured fundus and a diminished red reflex are classic for blood in the vitreous cavity — commonly from proliferative diabetic retinopathy in a patient with 20 years of diabetes. Retinal detachment usually causes a “curtain” and photopsias and often allows visualization of the detached retina, while CRAO produces severe, near-complete vision loss with a pale retina/cherry‑red spot rather than an obscured fundus.
raw_d:
Vitreous hemorrhage is the most likely diagnosis.

Reasoning: sudden onset of multiple dark streaks/floaters and acute blurring/darkening of vision, a fundus that is obscured and difficult to visualize, and a diminished red reflex are classic for blood in the vitreous cavity. Her 20‑year history of diabetes and smoking strongly predispose to proliferative diabetic retinopathy with vitreous hemorrhage. 

Why not anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION)? AION causes sudden painless vision loss with optic disc swelling/pallor and often an altitudinal field defect and a relative afferent pupillary defect; it does not produce floaters, obscure the fundus, or diminish the red reflex. Those features point to vitreous hemorrhage rather than AION.

question: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of sudden chest pain and dizziness. He smokes 30 cigarettes every day and has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia, which are being treated with amlodipine, metformin, and simvastatin, respectively. His heart rate is 103/min, oxygen saturation on room air is 91%, respiratory rate is 29/min, temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. On physical examination, he looks pale and diaphoretic. When his head is positioned at 45°, the external jugular vein filling level is 8 cm above the sternal angle. There is a severe decrease in respiratory sounds, hypoventilation in both bases, and occasional inspiratory crackles. The heart rate is arrhythmic without murmurs. The lower extremities are edematous. An electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in the right precordial leads. What is most consistent with this patient’s clinical presentation?
options: A. Cardiac tamponade B. Cardiogenic pulmonary edema C. Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction D. Right-sided heart failure
default:
